AStr.Run: Use this domain for general words referring to the physical universe. Some languages may not have a single word for the universe and may have to use a phrase such as 'rain, soil, and things of the sky' or 'sky, land, and water' or a descriptive phrase such as 'everything you can see' or 'everything that exists'.

LouwNidaCodes.Uni: 1A Universe, Creation; 14 Physical Events and States

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to everything we can see?

ExampleWords.AUni: universe, creation, cosmos, heaven and earth, macrocosm, everything that exists

AStr.Run: In the beginning God created <the heavens and the earth>.
Use this domain for words related to the sky.

Question.AUni: (3) What words are used to refer to the place or area beyond the sky?

ExampleWords.AUni: heaven, space, outer space, ether, void, solar system

Question.AUni: (4) What words describe something in the sky or something that happens in the sky?

ExampleWords.AUni: aerial, heavenly, atmospheric, stratospheric, celestial

Question.AUni: (5) What words describe the appearance of the sky?

ExampleWords.AUni: blue, clear, black (night), cloudy, cloud filled, brilliant, dark, night sky, foreboding, stormy, dark, star studded

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to the edge of the sky where it meets the ground?

ExampleWords.AUni: horizon, skyline

Question.AUni: (7) What words refer to something in the sky?

Question.AUni: (8) What words refer to the lights that appear in the northern (or southern) sky?

Question.AUni: (9) What words refer to something being in the sky?

ExampleWords.AUni: aloft, up in the sky, up in the air

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to the sun. The sun does three basic things. It moves, it gives light, and it gives heat. These three actions are involved in the meanings of most of the words in this domain. Since the sun moves below the horizon, many words refer to it setting or rising. Since the sun is above the clouds, many words refer to it moving behind the clouds and the clouds blocking its light. The sun's light and heat also produce secondary effects. The sun causes plants to grow, and it causes damage to things.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to the sun?

ExampleWords.AUni: sun, solar, sol, daystar, our star

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to how the sun moves?

ExampleWords.AUni: rise, set, cross the sky, come up, go down, sink

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to the time when the sun rises?

ExampleWords.AUni: dawn, sunrise, sunup, daybreak, cockcrow

AStr.Run: We got up before <dawn>, in order to get an early start.

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to the time when the sun is at its highest point?

ExampleWords.AUni: noon, zenith

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to the time when the sun sets?

ExampleWords.AUni: sunset, dusk, sundown, twilight, eventide

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to when the sun is shining?

ExampleWords.AUni: shine, sunny, bright, give light, be sunshiny, daytime

Question.AUni: (7) What words refer to the sun shining through the clouds?

ExampleWords.AUni: come out, break through (the clouds), go behind (a cloud)

Question.AUni: (8) What words describe where the sun is shining?

ExampleWords.AUni: sunlit, be (out) in the sun, lit by the sun, shine on, be in the sunlight, sunny (spot)

Question.AUni: (9) What words describe when or where the sun doesn't shine?

ExampleWords.AUni: shade, eclipse of the sun, sunless, shady, shadow, eclipse (v)

Question.AUni: (10) What words refer to the light of the sun?

ExampleWords.AUni: sunlight, ray, sunshine, beam, light, sunbeam, radiance, glow, sparkle, glisten, glare

Question.AUni: (11) What words describe the brightness of the sun?

ExampleWords.AUni: bright, intense, brilliant, blinding, glaring, glistening, luminous, dim

Question.AUni: (12) What refer to the sun heating things?

ExampleWords.AUni: warm, heat, dry

Question.AUni: (13) What else does the sun do?

ExampleWords.AUni: looks down on

Question.AUni: (14) What words describe the damage done by sunlight?

ExampleWords.AUni: sunburn, sunstroke, suntan, tan, heatstroke, heat prostration, sun damage, fading from the sun, bleached by the sun

Question.AUni: (15) What do people use to protect themselves from the sun?

ExampleWords.AUni: sunglasses, shade tree, suntan lotion, awning, sun umbrella, parasol, sunbonnet, hat, visor

ExampleWords.AUni: sundial, angle of the sun, sun-clock, shoot the sun, position of the sun

Question.AUni: (17) What words refer to using the power of the sun?

ExampleWords.AUni: solar energy, solar power, solar panel

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to the moon. In your culture people may believe things about the moon. For instance in European culture people used to believe that the moon caused people to become crazy. So in English we have words like "moon-struck" and "lunatic." You should include such words in this domain.

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to planets (large objects that circle the sun, looking like bright wandering stars in the sky), comets (objects that circle the sun, looking like a star with a tail), meteors (small objects that come from space and burn up when they hit the earth's atmosphere, causing a streak of light across the sky), and asteroids (small objects that circle the sun), planetary moons (large objects that circle the planets). Some cultures do not study the stars and will have few or no words in this domain. Others cultures that study the stars will have many words. There are only five planets that people can see in the sky--Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn. The others are only known from the scientific study of astronomy.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to a planet?

ExampleWords.AUni: planet, planetary, wandering star

Question.AUni: (2) What are the names of the planets?

ExampleWords.AUni: Mercury, Venus (Morning Star, Evening Star), Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune, Pluto

ExampleWords.AUni: revolve (around the sun), orbit

ExampleWords.AUni: asteroid, moon

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to the wind. Some words refer to when the wind begins and ends. The wind changes in speed, so some words refer to how fast the wind is moving. Try to rank these on a scale from very slow to very fast. These words may also be distinguished by what the wind does, since a fast wind does more things. These words may also be distinguished by how long the wind blows. Some words refer to the speed of the wind becoming faster or slower. Some words distinguish a steady wind from a wind in which the speed keeps changing. Some words refer to when the speed of the wind becomes faster for a short time. A steady wind moves in a particular direction, so there are words that include the direction of the wind. The direction of the wind may refer to the points of the compass, a neighboring geographical feature or area, or the direction in which the speaker is moving. Some words refer to a wind that moves in a small circle, making a pillar of dust or a funnel-shaped cloud. Some words refer to what the wind does, such as when it moves or damages something. People can feel the wind, so some words refer to how it feels. The wind makes noise, so there are words that refer to the sound of the wind. In some cultures there is a relation between the wind and spirits, so some words may refer to the activity of the spirits in the wind, or that the wind brings disease.

Question.AUni: (1) What general words refer to the wind?

ExampleWords.AUni: wind, windy, wind current

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe a wind that only lasts a short time?

ExampleWords.AUni: breath of air, puff of wind, gust, blast, flurry

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to earthquakes. In some languages earthquakes are thought of as moving somewhere. In Amele (PNG) they say "mim nen" which means 'the earthquake came down (from above)'. In Northern Embera an earthquake is a "house-shaking". They say "a house-shaking went."

AStr.Run: Use this domain for general words for all plants. Use a book of pictures to identify plant names and the scientific name. Languages divide plants into various domains that are not always comparable from language to language. Criterial features may be characteristics (trees and bushes are distinguished by size and number of trunks) and use (grass and weeds are distinguished by their desirability). A common distinction is between trees and non-trees, with trees described as being big, woody, and having a life expectancy of several years, while non-trees are small, non-woody, and have a life expectancy of typically not more than one year (Heine, Bernd and Karsten Legere. 1995. Swahili plants. Rudiger Koppe Verlag: Koln.). Agricultural societies will divide plants into wild and cultivated. However most plants for which there are names have some use. Therefore it does not seem helpful to divide plant names into domains for useful and non-useful plants. Since only parts of plants are eaten, edible parts of plants are listed under the domain 'Food'. Some languages may have more domains than are used in this list, others may have fewer. The classification system used here does not agree entirely with the system used by botanists. For instance botanists do not classify all the tree species together. The palm trees belong to the class Monocotyledoneae and are classified with lilies, bananas, and orchids. Apple and cherry trees belong to the class Dicotyledoneae and are classified in the rose family along with roses and blackberries. The acacia tree also belongs to the class Dicotyledoneae and is classified in the pulse family along with lupines and beans. However most folk taxonomies bring all the trees together. The scientific classification system for plants and animals is taken from: Carruth, Gorton, ed. 1989. The Volume Library, Vols. 1 and 2. The Southwestern Company: Nashville.

AStr.Run: Use this domain for trees--flowering plants with roots, stems, and leaves, which are large and have a wooden trunk (Phylum Spermatophyta, Subdivision Angiospermae). Also include the evergreen trees (Phylum Spermatophyta, Subdivision Gymnospermae). Evergreen trees do not have flowers, but have cone like fruits (pinecones) that contain seeds. Their leaves are shaped like needles and are retained for over a year.

AStr.Run: Use this domain for small plants that have roots, stems, flowers, and seeds, but do not have a wooden trunk (Phylum Spermatophyta, Subdivision Angiospermae). Also include the seedless plants, such as ferns (phylum Pteridophyta, class Filicineae), horsetails (phylum Pteridophyta, class Equisetineae), and club mosses (phylum Pteridophyta, class Lycopodineae). Plants of the Pteridophyta phylum have no flowers or seeds. Ferns have large, divided, feather-like leaves, or fronds. Club mosses are small (rarely over one meter) evergreen plants with simple leaves resembling pine or hemlock needles. Sometimes they grow upright, but often trail on the ground, where they propagate by means of runners. Horsetails send up tall, vertical, jointed stalks with branches covered with scale like leaves.

AStr.Run: Use this domain for mosses (phylum Bryophyta, class Musci), liverworts (phylum Bryophyta, class Hepaticae), fungi (phylum Thallophyta, subdivision Fungi), algae (phylum Thallophyta, subdivision Algae), and lichens. These plants do not have true roots, stems, or leaves. The mosses are small, green, flowerless plants that grow in moist environments and look like velvety or feathery growths carpeting the ground, tree trunks, and rocks. The liverworts are similar to the mosses with a flat and branching growth pattern. The algae possess green chlorophyll. They vary from one-celled organisms, which sometimes live in colonies such as pond scum, to complex organisms such as seaweed. The fungi do not possess chlorophyll and feed off of other organic material. Lichens consist of a fungus and an algae growing together. They commonly grow on trunks of trees and rocks. Some are flat and leafy, and some are moss like.

AStr.Run: Use this domain for general words referring to animals.

Question.AUni: (1) What general words refer to all animals?

ExampleWords.AUni: animal, fauna, creature, critter, organism, wildlife

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words describing types of animals. Use a book of pictures to identify each species and its scientific name. This section is organized according to the scientific, biological classification of animals. It may not correspond to the local classification of animals (folk taxonomy), which are often based on how people relate to animals (tame/wild, edible/work). Use this domain for words referring to large classes of animals that do not correspond to the scientific classification. For instance this would be the place for a word like 'flying animal', which includes birds, bats, and flying insects.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to types of animals?

ExampleWords.AUni: phylum, class, order, family, genus, species, chordate, vertebrate, invertebrate, crustacean, rodent, insect, arthropod, mollusk, echidna, protozoa, protozoan, protozoon, amoebic, amoeba, bacteriophage, cold-blooded, warm-blooded, multicellular, single-celled, unicellular, microorganism, germ, virus, viral, purebred, hybrid, quadruped, biped, two-footed, four-footed, diurnal, nocturnal, beast, brute, vermin, varmint, albino

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to male and female animals. Most languages have special words for the male and female of a species only for domesticated animals. Sometimes there will be a word for the male and not the female, and vice versa (male dog, bitch). Sometimes the word for one is also used generically (cow for both female and generic).

AStr.Run: Use this domain for general words for the whole human body, and general words for any part of the body. Use a drawing or photo to label each part. Some words may be more general than others are and include some of the other words. For instance 'head' is more general than 'face' or 'nose'. Be sure that both general and specific parts are labeled.

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to the female reproductive organs and a woman's monthly menstrual cycle. Some of these terms may be taboo. Care must be exercised in which terms are included in the dictionary. A group of women should decide which terms are 'public' and can go in the dictionary, and which would be considered taboo, overly crude, or embarrassing. For example some societies have been afraid that their women will be taken advantage of if these terms are known.

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to protesting--to say publicly that you do not like something.

ExampleWords.AUni: protest (v), object to, remonstrate, speak out against

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to many people protesting?

ExampleWords.AUni: storm of protest, outcry against, outcry over, public outcry, boycott

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to someone who protests?

ExampleWords.AUni: protester, demonstrator, dissident, marcher, objector

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to something someone protests about?

ExampleWords.AUni: protest (n), objection, remonstrance

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to many people protesting in a group?

ExampleWords.AUni: protest, demonstrate, march, boycott, riot, in protest

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to when many people protest in a group?

ExampleWords.AUni: protest (n), demonstration, march, rally, riot, unrest, civil disobedience, peaceful demonstration, placard

Question.AUni: (7) What words describe something done in protest?

ExampleWords.AUni: protest (adj)

Question.AUni: (8) What do people do when they are protesting against something?

ExampleWords.AUni: boo (v), boo (n), booing

Question.AUni: (9) What do people say when they are protesting against something?

ExampleWords.AUni: Down with (someone/something)! No more (something)!

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to a set of beliefs about truth.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to a set of beliefs about truth?

ExampleWords.AUni: philosophy, orientation, frame of reference, worldview

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to a person who attempts to define a set of beliefs?

ExampleWords.AUni: philosopher, sage

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to a group of philosophers?

ExampleWords.AUni: Epicurean, Stoic, school (of thought)

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to a person's attitude--the way you think and feel about something.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to a person's opinions and feelings about something?

ExampleWords.AUni: attitude, mentality, way of thinking, outlook, worldview

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to an extreme belief--something that you believe, that most people think is not good.

Question.AUni: (1) What words describe strong opinions and beliefs, which most people regard as extreme?

ExampleWords.AUni: extreme, hard-line, far-left, far-right, idealistic, out in left field

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to a person who holds extreme beliefs?

ExampleWords.AUni: extremist, hardliner, leftist, idealist, fanatic, zealot

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to changing your mind--to change what you think about something, or change your plans or decisions.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to changing a decision?

ExampleWords.AUni: change plans, change your mind, rethink, have second thoughts, backtrack, U-turn

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe a person who is willing to change his mind?

ExampleWords.AUni: open, open-minded

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to changing your mind many times?

ExampleWords.AUni: vacillate, go back and forth between, waver

Question.AUni: (4) What words describe a person who keeps changing his mind?

ExampleWords.AUni: fickle

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to refusing to change your mind?

ExampleWords.AUni: stand firm, stand your ground, stick to your guns

Question.AUni: (6) What words describe a person who refuses to change his mind?

ExampleWords.AUni: closed, close minded, rigid, inflexible, entrenched, reactionary, diehard, intransigent, have fixed ideas, stick in the mud

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to approving of doing something--to think that doing something is good.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to approving of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: approve, meet with someone's approval, agree with, believe in, condone, endorse, be for, be in favor of, okay (v), give it your okay, pass, sanction, subscribe, sustain, think something is right, uphold, value (v), think something is right

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to approving of something very much?

ExampleWords.AUni: be all for, be all in favor of, be a great believer in, be an advocate of

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to someone's approval?

ExampleWords.AUni: approval, approbation, advocacy, endorsement, sanction

Question.AUni: (4) What words describe something that someone approves of?

ExampleWords.AUni: admirable, creditable, estimable, honorable, meritorious

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to not approving of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: not approve, condemn, critical, critique, deprecate, disapprove of, disapproving, disqualify, frown on, invalidate, reject, take a dim view of, have a low opinion of, think badly of

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to someone's disapproval?

ExampleWords.AUni: disapproval, disapprobation, disfavor, rejection

Question.AUni: (7) What words describe something that someone does not approve of?

ExampleWords.AUni: abominable, blameworthy, deplorable, despicable, detestable, dishonorable, execrable, lamentable, reprehensible, unsatisfactory

Question.AUni: (8) What words refer to saying that you disapprove of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: voice your disapproval, express your disapproval, register your disapproval, condemn, denounce, deplore

Question.AUni: (9) What words refer to looking at someone in a disapproving way?

ExampleWords.AUni: give someone a disapproving look, give someone a dirty look, frown, look askance

Question.AUni: (10) What words describe something said in a disapproving way?

ExampleWords.AUni: disapproving, derogatory, pejorative

Question.AUni: (11) What words refer to when people start to disapprove of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: fall into disrepute

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to remembering something you know.

LouwNidaCodes.Uni: 29 Memory and Recall; 29B Recalling from Memory; 29D Recalling and Responding with Appropriate Action

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to remembering something?

ExampleWords.AUni: remember, recall, remind oneself, call to mind, bring to mind, think of, recognize, recognition, recollect, review, come (back) to, mindful, heed, think, in retrospect

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to memorizing something?

ExampleWords.AUni: memorize, commit to memory

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to causing someone to think of or remember something?

ExampleWords.AUni: remind, bring up, prompt, jog someone's memory, jog your mind

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to something that reminds a person of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: reminder, note, memo, memorandum, cue, souvenir, memorial, remembrance

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to remembering things that happened in the past?

ExampleWords.AUni: reminisce, recall, think back on

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to the things a person remembers?

ExampleWords.AUni: memory, recollection

Question.AUni: (7) What words refer to remembering to do something?

ExampleWords.AUni: heed, mind, mindful, respond

Question.AUni: (8) What words refer to remembering something good?

ExampleWords.AUni: cherish (a memory/thought), treasure

Question.AUni: (9) What words refer to remembering something bad?

ExampleWords.AUni: regret, rue the day

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to forgetting something.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to not remembering something?

ExampleWords.AUni: forget, didn't think of it, overlook, draw a blank, escape me, slip my mind, fly right out of your mind, lose your train of thought, lose track of

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to failing to remember to do something?

ExampleWords.AUni: neglect, omit, let something pass, slip, unmindful, miss

Question.AUni: (3) What words describe someone who has trouble remembering?

ExampleWords.AUni: forgetful, absentminded

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to forgetting many things because of a head injury?

ExampleWords.AUni: amnesia

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to recognizing something.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to recognizing something?

ExampleWords.AUni: distinguish, identify, know, place, realize, recognize, recognition, pick out, tell, not mistake

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe something that you can recognize?

ExampleWords.AUni: recognizable, familiar, unmistakable

Question.AUni: (3) What words describe something that you can't recognize?

ExampleWords.AUni: unrecognizable, unfamiliar, strange, changed beyond all recognition

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to memorizing something--to think hard about something so that you will not forget it.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to memorizing something?

ExampleWords.AUni: memorize, commit to memory, make a mental note, record, remember, store

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to reminding someone about something--to make someone remember something.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to reminding someone of something they must do or something they should know?

ExampleWords.AUni: remind, jog someone's memory, refresh someone's memory, prompt, be a reminder, reminder

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to reminding someone of a person or something that happened in the past?

ExampleWords.AUni: remind, be a reminder, bring back memories, take someone back, drag up, rake up, evoke, evocative, make someone think of

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to thinking about the future.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to how a person thinks about the future?

ExampleWords.AUni: expect, feel satisfied, feel dissatisfied, expect with certainty, expect uncertainly, be looking at, anticipate, await, suspense

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to something that may happen in the future?

ExampleWords.AUni: expectation, prospect, possibility

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to an expectation happening?

ExampleWords.AUni: come true, come about, be fulfilled, materialize

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to an expectation not happening?

ExampleWords.AUni: not come true, fail to materialize

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to hoping that something will happen--to want something good to happen in the future.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to hoping that something good will happen in the future?

ExampleWords.AUni: hope, look forward to, anticipate, eagerly await, bide, desire, dream, be optimistic, wish for, fulfill hope

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to something good that may happen in the future?

ExampleWords.AUni: hope (n), wish (n)

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to feeling hopeless--to thinking that nothing good will happen in the future.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to feeling hopeless?

ExampleWords.AUni: hopeless, lose hope, cynical, cynicism, despair, fatalistic, fatalism, pessimistic, pessimism

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to predicting the future--saying what you think will happen.

ExampleWords.AUni: claim, forecast, foretell, predict, prognosticate, prophesy

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words indicating that the speaker thinks that something tends to be a certain way.

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to wanting something or wanting to do something.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to wanting something?

ExampleWords.AUni: want, desire, wish, long for, yearn, crave, hunger, thirst, be attracted to, fancy, have a fancy for, intent on

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to wanting to do something?

ExampleWords.AUni: want to, wish you could, aspire to, feel like, hope you can, interested in, raring to, have an urge to

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to something someone wants?

ExampleWords.AUni: want (n), desire (n), wish (n), longing, yearning, craving, mania, obsession

Question.AUni: (4) What words describe something that people want?

ExampleWords.AUni: desirable

Question.AUni: (5) What words describe something that people don't want?

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to deciding to do something.

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to what is decided?

ExampleWords.AUni: decision, choice, plan, course, strategy

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to a goal--something that you want to do or something that you want to happen.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to the purpose of what you are doing?

ExampleWords.AUni: purpose, goal, aim (n), design (n), desire (n), destination, end, function, idea, intent, intention, object, objective, plan, the point, proposal, reason, target, use (n)

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to the purpose of something someone says?

ExampleWords.AUni: point, implication, mean, be driving at, be trying to say

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to the purpose of something like a machine or tool?

ExampleWords.AUni: function, use

Question.AUni: (4) What words indicate the purpose of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: for, be for, for the sake of, serve to, so, so that, to, toward, with a view to, with the aim of

Question.AUni: (5) What words indicate that something is done or made for a particular purpose?

ExampleWords.AUni: be meant to do something, supposed to do something, be intended to do something, be designed to do something

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to trying to reach a goal?

ExampleWords.AUni: to strive toward a goal, press on, aim for, endeavor, head for, try to accomplish

Question.AUni: (7) What words refer to reaching a goal?

ExampleWords.AUni: reach, attain, surpass

Question.AUni: (8) What words refer to failing to reach a goal?

ExampleWords.AUni: fail to reach, miss, fall short of

Question.AUni: (9) What words refer to not having any purpose?

ExampleWords.AUni: purposeless, without purpose, lack a goal, aimless, drifting, no direction

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to choosing something--to want one thing (or person) from a group of things, or to choose to do one thing from several possible things you could do.

LouwNidaCodes.Uni: 30F To Choose, To Select, To Prefer

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to choosing something?

ExampleWords.AUni: choose, select, prefer, decide on, pick, designate, elect, favor, opt for, specify, vote, would rather have

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to the thing that is chosen?

ExampleWords.AUni: choice, selection, preference, decision

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to the things that could be chosen?

ExampleWords.AUni: alternative, option, selection, candidate

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to casting lots--to make a decision by chance.

Question.AUni: (1) What is the general term for making a decision by chance?

ExampleWords.AUni: cast lots [in English and many languages there isn't a generic term; 'cast lots' is archaic]

Question.AUni: (2) What methods are used for making a decision by chance?

ExampleWords.AUni: roll a die, flip a coin, draw straws, pick names out of a hat, rock-paper-scissors, pick a card (out of a deck), count off, decide who goes first

Question.AUni: (3) What kind of decisions are made by these methods?

ExampleWords.AUni: deciding who goes first in a game, deciding who dies (e.g. who gets the life preserver), deciding who is guilty

Question.AUni: (4) What do people say when a decision has been made?

ExampleWords.AUni: X team has won the toss. OK, John goes first. I win. The Lord's will be done. It is the will of the gods. The gods have spoken.

Question.AUni: (5) What is the validating principle behind these methods?

ExampleWords.AUni: fate, chance, God's will, social consensus

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to intending to do something--to do something intentionally and not by accident.

LouwNidaCodes.Uni: 30D To Intend, To Purpose, To Plan

ExampleWords.AUni: intend, aim, expect, mean to do something, plan, purpose, resolve, be set on

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to what is intended?

ExampleWords.AUni: intent, intention, impulse, aim, purpose, resolution

Question.AUni: (3) What words describe something that someone intended to do?

ExampleWords.AUni: intentional, intentionally, on purpose, because I wanted to

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to doing something deliberately--to intend to do something, as opposed to doing something accidentally.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to doing something deliberately?

ExampleWords.AUni: deliberately, on purpose, intentionally, pointedly, make a point of, knowingly, consciously, willfully, mean to do something

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe something that is done deliberately?

ExampleWords.AUni: deliberate, intentional, conscious, calculated, premeditated

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to not doing something deliberately?

ExampleWords.AUni: accidentally, by accident, by mistake, unintentionally, not mean to do something, inadvertently, unconsciously

Question.AUni: (4) What words describe something that is not done deliberately?

ExampleWords.AUni: accidental, unintentional, unconscious, involuntary

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to being determined to do something--deciding to do something and not letting anything stop you.

LouwNidaCodes.Uni: 25O Patience, Endurance, Perseverance; 25F Be Eager, Be Earnest, In a Devoted Manner

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to being determined to do something?

ExampleWords.AUni: determined, aspire, be intent on, be set on, set your mind on, be resolved, mean business, purposefully, tenacious, put yourself into

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe a person who is determined?

ExampleWords.AUni: determined, adamant, committed, driven, hard headed, inexorable, inflexible, obdurate, persevering, pertinacious, single-minded, steadfast, strong-willed, stubborn, tenacious, uncompromising

Question.AUni: (3) What words describe a person's behavior that is determined?

ExampleWords.AUni: stubborn, steadfast, resolute, dogged, wholehearted

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to being so determined that you are even willing to do something bad?

ExampleWords.AUni: go to any lengths, be hell-bent on, whatever the cost, ruthless, stop at nothing

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to the quality of being determined?

ExampleWords.AUni: determination, ambition, commitment, drive, endurance, perseverance, pertinacity, resolve, spirit, fighting spirit, steadfastness, sticktoitiveness, tenacity, will, willpower

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to becoming more determined?

ExampleWords.AUni: stiffen your resolve, set your mind on, commit

Question.AUni: (7) What words refer to persevering in a task?

ExampleWords.AUni: persevere, give it your best, keep on, hang in there, endure, persist, plod, plug

Question.AUni: (8) What words refer to not being determined?

ExampleWords.AUni: apathetic, indifference, indifferent, listless, lethargic, neutral, nonchalant, uncaring

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to being stubborn--to be unwilling to change a decision; to be unwilling to do something someone wants you to do; or to do what you want to do, even though other people do not want you to do it.

Question.AUni: (1) What words describe someone who is stubborn?

ExampleWords.AUni: stubborn, adamant, bull-headed, conservative, dogged, enduring, hardened, hardheaded, headstrong, immovable, impenitent, incorrigible, indomitable, inflexible, intractable, mulish, obdurate, obstinate, persistent, pig-headed, recalcitrant, relentless, stiff-necked, strong-willed, stubborn, as stubborn as a mule, tenacious, unbending, uncompromising, ungovernable, unmanageable, unrepentant, unyielding, willful

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to a stubborn person?

ExampleWords.AUni: stubborn fool, mule, bulldog

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to being stubborn?

ExampleWords.AUni: refuse to obey/listen, won't listen to reason, stick to your guns

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to the quality of being stubborn?

ExampleWords.AUni: stubbornness, inflexibility, obstinacy, tenacity, sticktoitiveness

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to lusting for something--to want something bad or forbidden.

ExampleWords.AUni: desire, lust, avarice, burn, covet, crave, grasping, greed, inflamed

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to requesting something--to ask for something, or ask someone to do something.

ExampleWords.AUni: request, make a request, ask for something, ask somebody to do something, appeal, make an appeal, petition, requisition, solicit, apply, consult

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to what is said when someone makes a request?

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to asking for something when you are desperate to get it?

ExampleWords.AUni: implore, plead, beseech, entreat, importune

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to what is said when a person pleads?

ExampleWords.AUni: importunate

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to agreeing to do something.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to agreeing to do something?

ExampleWords.AUni: agree to do something, accept, approve a plan, consent to, give your consent, grant someone's request, jump at the chance, jump at the opportunity, OK something, give your OK, say yes, give something the thumbs up, take on

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to the act of agreeing to do something?

Question.AUni: (3) What do people say when they agree to do something?

Question.AUni: (4) What words indicate that you are doing something that someone has asked you to do?

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to refusing to do something.

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to suggesting something--saying that something might be good.

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to giving someone advice or counsel, for instance recommending a wise course of action.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to giving someone advice?

ExampleWords.AUni: advise, say someone should do something, give advice, recommend, urge, offer advice, advocate, commend, counsel, present, promote, propose, recommend a course of action, guide, instruct, submit, make a motion, exhort

Question.AUni: (2) What words do people use when giving advice?

ExampleWords.AUni: if I were you, you should do something, you ought to, you'd be better off, take my advice, take it from me, you'd be well advised to do something, on no account, you'd better, I would

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to doing what someone advises?

ExampleWords.AUni: take someone's advice, follow someone's advice, listen to advice, act on someone's advice, accept advice, adopt

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to the advice that a person gives?

ExampleWords.AUni: advice, tip, recommendation, guidance, counseling, counsel, instructions, idea, proposal, charge

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to someone who gives advice?

ExampleWords.AUni: adviser, counselor, consultant, guru, mentor, coach

Question.AUni: (7) What words refer to a group of people who give advice?

ExampleWords.AUni: council, board, committee, advisory (board)

Question.AUni: (8) What words refer to needing advice?

ExampleWords.AUni: need advice, don't know what to do

Question.AUni: (9) What words refer to not knowing what to advise?

ExampleWords.AUni: don't know what to tell you

Question.AUni: (10) What words refer to not accepting advice?

ExampleWords.AUni: refuse advice, ignore advice

Question.AUni: (11) What words refer to giving advice when the person doesn't want it?

ExampleWords.AUni: meddle, kibitz, kibitzer

Question.AUni: (12) What words describe good or bad advice?

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words that express the idea that something (said, written, thought, or made) depicts or is about a subject, or that something is logically related to some topic. Also use this domain for words that mark the topic or subject of what is being thought about, talked about, or written about. Verbs of thinking, knowing, or speaking (including other types of expression) can take a 'topic' role. We can think of a 'topic' as the main idea. Use this domain also for the important thing in a picture.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to being about something or someone?

ExampleWords.AUni: be about something, concern, deal with, be concerned with, center on, focus on, address, cover, depict, discuss, dwell on, present, portray, treat

AStr.Run: The book <is about> the President.; The meeting <is about> the schedule.; The story <depicts> the life of the President.; The story <presents> a view of the President.

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate what something is about?

ExampleWords.AUni: about, on, concerning, on the subject of, regarding, re, with regard to, in, of

AStr.Run: John was talking <about> the new seed he bought.; I read <about> John in the newspaper.; a book <about> the President; the book <on> the President; the picture <of> the President; an experiment <concerning> growing rice; a course <in> history

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to the thing something is about?

ExampleWords.AUni: subject, topic, theme, issue, question, matter, business, thing

AStr.Run: The <subject> of the book is the President.; The <topic> of the discussion is efficiency.

Question.AUni: (5) What do people say when they thank someone?

AStr.Run: Thank you. Thanks. That's very kind of you. That's very good of you. I appreciate it. You shouldn't have, You've saved my life. I'd like to thank. Many thanks. Bless you. Blessings on you. Much obliged. I'm indebted to you. I'm in your debt. I'm beholden to you.

AStr.Run: Use this domain for obscene words related to sex, defecation, death, damnation, and other taboo or offensive subjects. It is important to check the appropriateness of including obscene words in the dictionary. It should be the choice of the speakers of the language whether a word should be included or excluded. Obscene words included in the dictionary should be clearly marked as such. Obscenity is often used to heighten the emotion of an expression, and is often used when someone is angry. Obscenity is often associated with sex or defecation. Cursing is often associated with God, religion, or the afterlife. Insults often involve equating a person with an animal that is associated with an undesirable characteristic, questioning someone's parentage/legitimacy, questioning someone's character, or questioning someone's intelligence/sanity.

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to deserving something--if you do something, either good or bad, something can happen to you as a result of what you did. For instance you can receive a reward for doing good, or a punishment for doing wrong. If what happened to you is like what you did, people can think it is right that this thing happened to you.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to deserving what you receive?

ExampleWords.AUni: deserve, merit, be owed, be yours by right, have earned

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that someone deserves the problems they are having?

ExampleWords.AUni: deserve, had it coming, get what you deserve, serve someone right, get your just deserts, get what was coming to you, your punishment fits the crime

Question.AUni: (3) What words describe something that someone deserves?

ExampleWords.AUni: well-deserved, well-earned, fitting, appropriate

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to fighting someone. The words in this domain describe a situation in which two people or groups of people fight each other over something or in order to reach some goal. A fight can use words, various kinds of weapons, or other actions. For fights that only use words use the domain 'Quarrel'.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to enemies fighting?

ExampleWords.AUni: fight, have a fight, get into a fight, fighting, battle, brawl, bully, clash, come to blows, confront, duel, engage (the enemy), face (an enemy), feud, jostle, joust, oppose, scuffle, set-to, spar, skirmish, squabble, strive, struggle, tussle, war, wrestle, be in the fray, go on the warpath

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to a fight?

ExampleWords.AUni: affray, altercation, battle (n), bout, combat, conflict, contest, crisis, duel (n), feud (n), gunfight, row, shootout, showdown, skirmish, spat, squabble, strife, struggle (n), tiff, war (n)

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to a fight between a few people?

ExampleWords.AUni: fight (n), brawl (n), fracas, fray, free-for-all, melee, scrap, scuffle (n)

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to a fight between many people?

ExampleWords.AUni: fighting, battle, clash (n), confrontation

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to a fight that neither side can win?

ExampleWords.AUni: stalemate, standoff

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to someone causing a fight?

ExampleWords.AUni: arouse, challenge, embroil, fan the flames, goad, incite, instigate, provoke, rally, rouse, spur, stir up

Question.AUni: (7) What words refer to someone who is fighting?

ExampleWords.AUni: fighter, hooligan

ExampleWords.AUni: stop fighting, cease hostilities, end adversity, make peace, make amends, apologize, apology, reconcile, reconciliation, make up, disengage, settle, peace offering, pacify, appease, quell, tranquilize, neutralize, harmonize, harmonious

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to talking about stopping fighting?

ExampleWords.AUni: negotiate, negotiations, entreat

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to an agreement to stop fighting?

ExampleWords.AUni: ceasefire, truce, armistice, peace treaty

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to reconciling with someone.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to enemies becoming reconciled?

ExampleWords.AUni: make amends, reconcile, ameliorate, restore, make up, make peace, pacify

AStr.Run: Use this domain for general words referring to religion and the supernatural.

OcmCodes.Uni: 770 Religious Beliefs; 771 General Character of Religion

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to the system of belief and practice related to God?

ExampleWords.AUni: religion, religious system, faith

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to what is beyond our senses or ability?

ExampleWords.AUni: supernatural, magic, miracle, miraculous, paranormal

Question.AUni: (3) What words describe something having to do with religion?

ExampleWords.AUni: religious, sacred, spiritual

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to those areas of life outside of religion?

ExampleWords.AUni: secular, profane

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to the world of gods and spirits?

ExampleWords.AUni: spirit world, spiritual realm, the supernatural, the unseen

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to God--the supreme being in the universe. Each theological system will have different beliefs concerning the existence and nature of God. Our purpose here is to collect and define the terms used to refer to the supreme deity. If there is no such person in the theological system, then use this domain for other terms for the pantheon of gods, ultimate reality, nirvana, and similar concepts. However most theological systems, even atheism, have the concept of a supreme God and use words to refer to him.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to the supreme being in the universe?

ExampleWords.AUni: God, the Lord, Yahweh, Elohim, Allah, Theos, Deus, Sky God, supreme being, supreme deity

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to what people believe about God?

ExampleWords.AUni: theology, monotheism, polytheism, pantheism, atheism

Question.AUni: (3) What words describe something to do with God?

ExampleWords.AUni: divine

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to supernatural beings--gods, spirits, other types of beings, which normally cannot be seen and do not belong to this world. Some people accept the existence of certain supernatural beings and not others. Mythological beings are those that were believed in during previous times but that are no longer believed in. Fictional beings are those that no one has ever believed in. An indication of whether most people believe in the supernatural being should be put in the definition.

LouwNidaCodes.Uni: 12 Supernatural Beings and Powers; 12A Supernatural Beings

Question.AUni: (1) What general words refer to supernatural beings?

ExampleWords.AUni: supernatural being, spirit

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to lesser gods?

ExampleWords.AUni: god, goddess, the gods, pantheon, deity

Question.AUni: (3) What types of good supernatural beings are there?

ExampleWords.AUni: angel, angelic being, cherub, seraph, saint

Question.AUni: (4) What types of evil supernatural beings are there?

ExampleWords.AUni: demon, devil, Satan, the Devil, Beelzebub

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to the spirit of a dead person?

ExampleWords.AUni: spirit, ghost, specter, apparition, phantom, shade, ghoul

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to supernatural beings that are considered to be mythological or fictional and not real?

ExampleWords.AUni: Santa Claus, elf, fairy, giant, dwarf, sprite, genie, dragon, monster, Cyclops, vampire, alien

Question.AUni: (7) What words describe something like or related to a supernatural being?

ExampleWords.AUni: divine, angelic, demonic, Satanic, devilish, diabolical, ghost like, ghoulish, monstrous, alien

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to theology--the study of God and what people believe about God.

OcmCodes.Uni: 779 Theological Systems; 770 Religious Beliefs; 772 Cosmology; 773 Mythology; 774 Animism; 775 Eschatology

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to the study of God and religion?

ExampleWords.AUni: theology

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to something you believe about God?

ExampleWords.AUni: doctrine, tenet, dogma, belief

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to disagreement over doctrine?

ExampleWords.AUni: heterodoxy, sect, denomination, dissent

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to foolish or ignorant beliefs about religion?

ExampleWords.AUni: superstition

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to sacred writings. Examples are only given for the Christian sacred writings. However you should include words referring to the holy books of all religions .

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to sacred writings?

ExampleWords.AUni: sacred writings, Scripture, Bible, the Good Book, Gospel

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to a part of the sacred writings?

ExampleWords.AUni: chapter, verse, text, Old/New Testament, Law, Prophets, Gospels, Epistles, Apocalypse

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to God's role in producing sacred writings?

ExampleWords.AUni: inspire, inspiration, revelation

Question.AUni: (4) What words describe the sacred writings or a text from the sacred writings?

ExampleWords.AUni: inspired, holy, scriptural, biblical, sacred, prophetic, apostolic

Question.AUni: (5) What words describe whether or not a book should be considered a part of the sacred writings?

ExampleWords.AUni: canon, canonical, apocryphal

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to a book that is revered but not considered part of the sacred writings?

ExampleWords.AUni: Apocrypha

Question.AUni: (7) What words refer to the interpretation of sacred writings?

ExampleWords.AUni: interpretation, exegesis

Question.AUni: (8) What words refer to a book that interprets the sacred writings?

ExampleWords.AUni: commentary

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to miracles--the use of supernatural power to do something good.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to supernatural power?

ExampleWords.AUni: supernatural power, miraculous power, might, force, omnipotence, almighty, all-powerful

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to performing a miracle?

ExampleWords.AUni: perform a miracle, produce a miracle, do a miracle

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to the event of a miracle?

ExampleWords.AUni: miracle, miraculous event, sign, wonder, magic

Question.AUni: (4) What words describe a miracle?

ExampleWords.AUni: miraculous

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to a person who can perform miracles?

ExampleWords.AUni: miracle worker, prophet

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to sorcery--the use of supernatural power to do something bad.

OcmCodes.Uni: 789 Magic; 754 Sorcery; 755 Magical and Mental Therapy

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to doing something using sorcery?

ExampleWords.AUni: practice sorcery, do magic, work magic, cast a spell, put a spell on, put a curse on, bewitch, conjure, invoke, enchant, bedevil, entrance (v), mesmerize, wave a wand, jinx

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to the practice of sorcery?

ExampleWords.AUni: sorcery, magic (n), witchcraft, black magic, voodoo, voodooism, witchery, wizardry, occult, necromancy

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to something that someone does using sorcery?

ExampleWords.AUni: spell, curse, hex, enchantment, charm, incantation

Question.AUni: (4) What is a person called who practices sorcery?

ExampleWords.AUni: sorcerer, magician, witch, wizard, shaman, witchdoctor, conjurer, necromancer, warlock, charmer, medicine man, alchemist, medium

Question.AUni: (5) What words describe someone or something that can do magic?

ExampleWords.AUni: have magical powers, magic (adj), magical, supernatural, occult, mystic, weird

Question.AUni: (6) What words describe someone who has been bewitched?

ExampleWords.AUni: charmed, bewitched, spellbound, haunted

Question.AUni: (7) What words refer to protecting someone from sorcery?

ExampleWords.AUni: ward off

Question.AUni: (8) What things are used when performing sorcery?

ExampleWords.AUni: charm, amulet, evil eye, talisman, fetish, wand, rod, divining rod, magic ring, philosopher's stone, magic carpet, cauldron

Question.AUni: (9) What words are used when performing sorcery?

ExampleWords.AUni: abracadabra, open sesame

Question.AUni: (10) What words refer to malevolent supernatural power?

ExampleWords.AUni: malevolent power, evil force, Satanic force, demonic power, black magic

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to demon possession--when a demon or spirit influences or controls the behavior of a person. Use this domain for all words related to the relationship between spirits and people, including communication between people and spirits. Also use this domain for words referring to casting out demons--causing a demon to stop influencing or controlling a person.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to being influenced or controlled by a demon?

ExampleWords.AUni: be possessed, be demonized, go into a trance

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to what demons do to people?

ExampleWords.AUni: possess, inhabit, demonize, torture, haunt, trouble

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to casting out a demon?

ExampleWords.AUni: cast out a demon, exorcise, drive out, expel, deliver/free/release from demonic power/influence

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to a person who casts out demons?

ExampleWords.AUni: exorcist

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to blessing someone--saying something that causes something good to happen, or requests God to do something good to someone.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to blessing someone?

ExampleWords.AUni: bless, pronounce a blessing, give a blessing, bestow a blessing, invoke

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to what is said in blessing?

ExampleWords.AUni: blessing, benediction

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to cursing someone.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to cursing someone?

ExampleWords.AUni: curse, put/place a curse on, be under a curse, be cursed

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to the curse place on someone?

ExampleWords.AUni: curse, anathema

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to destiny--decisions and actions by God, spirits, or by impersonal forces that determine or influence what happens to a person.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to the decisions God makes concerning what happens to a person?

ExampleWords.AUni: God's will, providence

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to an impersonal force that determines what happens to a person?

ExampleWords.AUni: destiny, fate, fortune, luck, chance, throw of the dice

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to something to which a person or thing is destined?

ExampleWords.AUni: destiny, fate

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to speaking for God, including foretelling the future through divine knowledge.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to being able to speak for God or deliver a message from God?

ExampleWords.AUni: prophesy, foretell the future, predict the future

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to what is said?

ExampleWords.AUni: prophecy, prediction, prophetic utterance

Question.AUni: (3) What is a person called who speaks for God or foretells the future?

ExampleWords.AUni: prophet, prophetess

Question.AUni: (4) What words describe something said in prophecy?

ExampleWords.AUni: prophetic

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to supernatural knowledge.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to supernatural knowledge?

ExampleWords.AUni: supernatural knowledge, foreknowledge, supernatural insight, ability to interpret dreams

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to being able to divine secrets?

ExampleWords.AUni: divine, read the signs, foretell the future

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to the practice of divining secrets?

ExampleWords.AUni: divination, palmistry, fortune telling, astrology

Question.AUni: (4) What is a person called who can divine secrets?

ExampleWords.AUni: diviner, fortuneteller, astrologer

Question.AUni: (5) What words describe someone who can divine secrets?

ExampleWords.AUni: clairvoyant

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to something showing what will happen in the future?

ExampleWords.AUni: augur, betoken, bode, forebode, foreshadow, foretell, foretoken, ominous, portend, prefigure, presage

Question.AUni: (7) What words refer to something that shows or tells a secret?

ExampleWords.AUni: omen, sign, harbinger, portent, presage, foreshadowing, message from the beyond

Question.AUni: (8) What methods are used to divine secrets?

ExampleWords.AUni: interpret dreams, read palms, read tea leaves, read cards, read the stars, consult your horoscope, look into a crystal ball, play with a Ouija board, examine the entrails of an animal

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to practicing religion.

OcmCodes.Uni: 780 Religious Practices; 781 Religious Experience; 786 Ecstatic Religious Practices; Orgies

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to practicing religion?

ExampleWords.AUni: practice your religion, serve God

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to being devout.

Question.AUni: (1) What words describe someone who practices his religion with devotion?

ExampleWords.AUni: devout, devoted, devotion, committed, pious, religious, zealous, saintly, holy

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe someone who is not devout?

ExampleWords.AUni: uncommitted, nominal, lukewarm

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to praying--talking to God.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to praying to God?

ExampleWords.AUni: pray, talk to God, beseech

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to prayer?

ExampleWords.AUni: prayer, supplication, intercession, petition, thanksgiving, grace, benediction

Question.AUni: (3) What actions or postures symbolize prayer?

ExampleWords.AUni: bow your head, kneel, fold your hands

AStr.Run: Use this domain for personal expressions of devotion to God, in whatever ways the religion defines and expresses it.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to relating to God or to the spirits?
(2) What words refer to acts of worship toward God?

ExampleWords.AUni: worship, adore, revere, reverence, lift up your heart, pay homage

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to the act of worship?

ExampleWords.AUni: worship, adoration, devotion, homage, service, reverence, veneration, deification, idolization

Question.AUni: (4) What actions or postures symbolize worship?

ExampleWords.AUni: bow, kneel, genuflect, prostrate oneself

Question.AUni: (5) What types of actions make up worship?

ExampleWords.AUni: prayer, singing hymns, praising God

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to religious ceremonies.

OcmCodes.Uni: 796 Organized Ceremonial; 788 Ritual; 786 Ecstatic religious practices; Orgies

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to performing a religious ceremony?

ExampleWords.AUni: perform a religious ceremony, hold communion

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to a religious ceremony?

ExampleWords.AUni: religious ceremony, worship service, church service, time of prayer, prayer meeting, Bible study, liturgy, invocation

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to offering a sacrifice.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to offering a sacrifice?

ExampleWords.AUni: sacrifice, offer a sacrifice, offer up, burn on the altar, devote, consecrate

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to offering a sacrifice?

ExampleWords.AUni: sacrifice, offering, devotion, consecration

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to what is sacrificed?

ExampleWords.AUni: sacrifice, offering, burnt offering, votive offering, gift

Question.AUni: (4) What words describe a sacrifice?

ExampleWords.AUni: sacrificial (giving, lamb), devoted, consecrated

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to religious purification.

OcmCodes.Uni: 783 Purification and Atonement; Purification and Expiation; 783 Purification and Expiation; 688 Religious Offenses

LouwNidaCodes.Uni: 88C Holy, Pure; 53C Purify, Cleanse; 53D Defiled, Unclean, Common; 53E Baptize

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to purifying someone or something for religious purposes?

ExampleWords.AUni: purify, purification, cleanse, cleansing, wash, washing, sprinkle, sprinkling, baptize, baptism

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe something that has been purified?

ExampleWords.AUni: be pure, undefiled, unpolluted, washed, sprinkled

Question.AUni: (3) What words describe something that has not been purified?

ExampleWords.AUni: be impure, defiled, polluted, unwashed

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to something that causes impurity?

ExampleWords.AUni: impurity, defilement, pollution

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to things that are taboo--something to be avoided; a religious, social, or cultural restriction on behavior, as opposed to a government law.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to a cultural restriction on behavior?

ExampleWords.AUni: taboo, prohibition

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to making something taboo?

ExampleWords.AUni: make taboo, forbid, prohibit, ban

Question.AUni: (3) What words describe something that is taboo?

ExampleWords.AUni: taboo, forbidden, prohibited, untouchable, inviolable, banned, off-limits, avoided

AStr.Run: Use this domain for the primary goal or goals of a religion, for instance in Christianity salvation from sin, death and Hell. Each religion has different beliefs about salvation. Our purpose here is not to preach or argue, but to list those words that people use to talk about this topic.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to what God does to save a person?

ExampleWords.AUni: save, salvation, sanctify, redeem, justify, regenerate

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to a person who saves another?

ExampleWords.AUni: savior

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to what a person does to be saved?

ExampleWords.AUni: believe, repent, return (to God), receive, work, earn

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to dedicating someone or something to religious use.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to dedicating something to religious use?

ExampleWords.AUni: dedicate, consecrate, anoint, sanctify, devote, hallow, baptize, circumcise

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe something that has been dedicated?

ExampleWords.AUni: holy, consecrated, sanctified, sacred, devoted, baptized

Question.AUni: (3) What words describe something that has not been dedicated?

ExampleWords.AUni: unholy, common

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to improperly using something that has been dedicated?

ExampleWords.AUni: desecrate

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to fasting--to not eat for a period of time.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to not eating for a period of time?

ExampleWords.AUni: fast, deny (oneself)

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to a person who denies himself for religious purposes?

ExampleWords.AUni: ascetic

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to the general practice of denying oneself something?

ExampleWords.AUni: asceticism

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to a time when a person fasts or denies himself in some other way?

ExampleWords.AUni: fast, Lent, Ramadan

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to heaven and hell--the place where people go after they die.

LouwNidaCodes.Uni: 1C Regions Below the Surface of the Earth

Question.AUni: (1) What is the place or home of God called?

ExampleWords.AUni: Heaven, the highest heaven, the abode of God, the throne of God

Question.AUni: (2) What is the place called where dead people are?

ExampleWords.AUni: Hades, Sheol, the place of the dead, the grave, the other side, the beyond, underworld, nether world

Question.AUni: (3) What is the place called where believers (good people) go when they die?

ExampleWords.AUni: heaven, paradise, your reward

Question.AUni: (4) What is the place called where unbelievers (bad people) go when they die?

ExampleWords.AUni: hell, the pit, fire and brimstone, eternal damnation

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to going to heaven or hell?

ExampleWords.AUni: pass on, go to heaven, go to hell

Question.AUni: (6) What words describe something belonging to heaven or hell?

ExampleWords.AUni: celestial, heavenly, hellish

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to resurrection--life after death, or living again after dying.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to coming back to life?

ExampleWords.AUni: come back to life, come back from the grave, come to life, resurrection

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to causing someone to come back to life?

ExampleWords.AUni: resurrect, raise from the dead, bring back to life, bring back from the dead

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to the condition or state of living forever?

ExampleWords.AUni: live forever, (have) eternal life, life everlasting, immortality, life after death

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to reincarnation?

ExampleWords.AUni: reincarnation, reincarnated

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to official religions, groups within a religion, and religious meetings. Each religion will have different names for its groups. Answer each question for each religion.

OcmCodes.Uni: 779 Theological Systems; 790 Ecclesiastical Organization; 794 Congregations; 795 Religious Denominations; Sects; 797 Missions

Question.AUni: (1) What general words refer to an official religion?

ExampleWords.AUni: religion, faith

Question.AUni: (2) What are the names of the official religions?

ExampleWords.AUni: Christianity, Islam, Hinduism, Judaism, animism, paganism

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to a group within a religion?

ExampleWords.AUni: sect, denomination, party

Question.AUni: (4) What are the names of the sects?

ExampleWords.AUni: Catholic, Protestant, Baptist, Presbyterian, Methodist

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to a group of believers in a particular place?

ExampleWords.AUni: church, congregation, diocese, parish

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to beginning to believe in a religion or changing from one religion to another?

ExampleWords.AUni: convert, conversion

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to religious practitioners--people who practice a religion, who are members of the religion, believe in the religion, leaders of the religion, and followers of the religion. Each religion has its own terms for religious practitioners. List these terms separately for each religion. The examples given below are for the Christian religion.

OcmCodes.Uni: 791 Magicians and Diviners; 792 Prophets and Ascetics; Holy Men; 793 Priesthood

LouwNidaCodes.Uni: 31J Be a Believer, Christian Faith; 53I Roles and Functions

ExampleWords.AUni: believer, member (of the faith), adherent, follower, practitioner

Question.AUni: (2) What is a person called who believes in the (Christian) religion?

ExampleWords.AUni: Christian, brother, fellow believer, saint

Question.AUni: (3) What is a leader of the (Christian-Protestant) religion called?

ExampleWords.AUni: pastor, minister, parson

Question.AUni: (4) What is a leader of the (Christian-Catholic) religion called?

ExampleWords.AUni: priest, father, bishop, archbishop, Cardinal, pope, man of the cloth

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to the profession of being a religious leader?

ExampleWords.AUni: pastorate, priesthood, ministry

Question.AUni: (6) What words refers to all religious leaders?

ExampleWords.AUni: clergy

Question.AUni: (7) What words refer to followers of a religion who are not leaders?

ExampleWords.AUni: laity, layperson, flock

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to thinking and acting against God or religion.

Question.AUni: (1) What is a person called who does not believe in a religion?

ExampleWords.AUni: unbeliever, pagan, gentile, heathen, atheist, agnostic, irreligious, godless

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to a religious group, which the official religion considers to be false?

ExampleWords.AUni: false religion, sect

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to a belief, which the official religion considers to be false?

ExampleWords.AUni: heresy, heretical, heretic, false doctrine/teaching

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to thinking against God?

ExampleWords.AUni: disbelieve, unbelief, lack of faith, doubt, skepticism, agnosticism, atheism, paganism

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to speaking against God?

ExampleWords.AUni: blaspheme, scoff, profane, irreverent

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to acting against God?

ExampleWords.AUni: sin, impiety, ungodly, godlessness, desecrate, sacrilege

Question.AUni: (7) What words describe someone who is against God?

ExampleWords.AUni: impious, irreligious, profane

Question.AUni: (8) What words refer to turning away from God?

ExampleWords.AUni: apostasy, backsliding, reprobate

Question.AUni: (9) What words refer to pretending to be religious?

ExampleWords.AUni: hypocrisy, hypocrite

Question.AUni: (10) What words refer to extreme beliefs that are evil?

ExampleWords.AUni: fanatic, fanaticism, bigot, bigotry

Question.AUni: (11) What words refer to religious practices that are done in ignorance?

ExampleWords.AUni: superstition

Question.AUni: (12) What words refer to allowing other people to practice their religion?

ExampleWords.AUni: tolerance, intolerance

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to adding spice to food?

ExampleWords.AUni: spice, flavor, season

Question.AUni: (4) What words describe food to which spice has been added?

ExampleWords.AUni: spicy, flavorful, seasoned

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to leaven?

ExampleWords.AUni: leaven, yeast, baking powder (sodium bicarbonate), rising agent

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to adding leaven to food?

ExampleWords.AUni: leaven

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to what happens to food when leaven is added?

ExampleWords.AUni: rise, ferment

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to cooking oil.

ExampleWords.AUni: cooking oil, oil, margarine, shortening

Question.AUni: (2) What seeds are used to make oil?

ExampleWords.AUni: olive, corn, canola, cottonseed

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to prepared food. Cultures vary widely in the number and types of foods they prepare, and in how they classify them. For instance the English distinction between main dish and side dish is not found in the classification system of other languages. If your language has well-recognized subcategories, you can set up a separate subdomain for each. The questions below are based on the main ingredient in the dish.

Question.AUni: (1) What general words refer to prepared food?

ExampleWords.AUni: cooked food, prepared food, dish, course

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to a major class of prepared food?

ExampleWords.AUni: main dish, side dish, meat dish, casserole, vegetable, staple, bread, soup, salad, fruit, condiment, dessert, candy, cookie, sweets, savories, snack

Question.AUni: (3) What general words refer to a food made primarily from meat?

ExampleWords.AUni: meat dish, main dish, main course

Question.AUni: (4) What types of foods are made primarily from meat?

ExampleWords.AUni: roast beef, steak, fried chicken, fish and chips, hamburger, hot dog, pizza, spaghetti, casserole, lasagna, stew

Question.AUni: (5) What foods are made primarily from staple foods?

ExampleWords.AUni: mashed potatoes and gravy, pasta, cooked rice, stuffing, oatmeal, porridge, cereal, mush

Question.AUni: (6) What types of bread are there?

ExampleWords.AUni: bread, pastry, brown bread, white bread, biscuit, muffin, roll, sweetbread, sandwich, tortilla, toast, loaf

Question.AUni: (7) What foods are made primarily from fruit?

ExampleWords.AUni: cranberry sauce, applesauce, fruit salad

Question.AUni: (8) What foods are made primarily from vegetables?

ExampleWords.AUni: side dish, vegetable, carrot sticks, onion rings

Question.AUni: (9) What foods are made primarily from leaves and stems?

ExampleWords.AUni: salad, tossed salad, green salad, coleslaw

Question.AUni: (10) What words refer to foods that contain a lot of water and are boiled?

ExampleWords.AUni: soup, tomato soup, split green pea soup, clam chowder, broth, stew, gravy

Question.AUni: (11) What types of condiments are there (foods that people only eat a little of, because they are expensive, strong tasting, or are added to other foods to flavor them)?

ExampleWords.AUni: condiment, garnish, pickle, olive, black olive, green olive, tomato sauce, ketchup, mustard, mayonnaise, peanut butter, jam, jelly, preserves

Question.AUni: (12) What words refer to sweet foods?

ExampleWords.AUni: dessert, sweet (n), cake, ice cream, pie, cobbler, cookie, cinnamon roll, candy, chocolate, chocolate bar, pudding, lollipop, syrup, treacle

Question.AUni: (13) What foods are eaten away from home (for instance on a journey or at work)?

ExampleWords.AUni: sack lunch, picnic lunch, dried food, C-rations, fast food

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words that describe food that is prohibited by the culture or religion. Do not list the foods that are prohibited.

Question.AUni: (1) What words describe food that is prohibited?

ExampleWords.AUni: prohibited food, taboo food, unclean

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe food that is not prohibited?

ExampleWords.AUni: kosher

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to narcotics and drugs that are not used as medicine but as stimulants. Narcotics are often addicting and harmful to a person's health.

ExampleWords.AUni: addict, user, junkie

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to a dosage of drugs?

ExampleWords.AUni: joint

Question.AUni: (7) What affect do drugs have on people?

ExampleWords.AUni: addiction, dependence, be high

Question.AUni: (8) What words refer to being addicted to drugs?

ExampleWords.AUni: be addicted, dependent, be hooked

Question.AUni: (9) What words refer to the need for drugs?

ExampleWords.AUni: addiction, habit, dependence

Question.AUni: (10) What words describe a drug that makes people addicted?

ExampleWords.AUni: addictive

ExampleWords.AUni: stimulant

ExampleWords.AUni: coffee, tea, mate, hookah, chewing gum, beetle nut

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to special clothes worn on special occasions. It is necessary to think through all the various special occasions in the culture and think of any special clothes worn on those occasions. Two examples are given below for work and graduation, but there are many others.

Question.AUni: (1) What general words refer to clothes worn on a special occasion?

ExampleWords.AUni: sports clothes, work clothes, formal clothes, informal, office wear

Question.AUni: (2) What special clothes are worn for work?

ExampleWords.AUni: work clothes, overalls, coveralls, apron, work gloves, hardhat, steel-toed shoes, boots, goggles

Question.AUni: (3) What special clothes are worn for graduation?

ExampleWords.AUni: cap and gown

AStr.Run: Use this domain for special clothes worn by special people. It is necessary to think through all the various special types of people in the culture and think of any special clothes worn by them. Several examples are given below, but there are many others.

Question.AUni: (1) What special clothes are worn by police or soldiers?

ExampleWords.AUni: uniform, dress uniform, fatigues, camouflage, helmet, beret, cap, gas mask, braid

ExampleWords.AUni: police uniform, military uniform, nurse's uniform, band uniform

Question.AUni: (5) What special clothes are worn by doctors?

ExampleWords.AUni: greens, surgical suit, white coat, nurses cap

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to wearing clothing.

ExampleWords.AUni: to dress, get dressed, put on, clothe, get into, throw on, jump into, don, tuck in, button, zip, tie

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to taking clothing off?

ExampleWords.AUni: to undress, get undressed, take off, strip, rip off, get out of

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to not wearing a piece of clothing?

ExampleWords.AUni: barefoot, shoeless, shirtless, hatless, unshod, topless

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to being naked--not wearing any clothes, and for words referring to how a person feels about being naked. It is a part of universal human experience that people do not want to be naked. So there are words that refer to feeling bad if one does not have enough clothes on (shame). Other words refer to wanting to have enough clothes (modest). Other words refer to how people feel about other people who do not wear enough clothes (indecent).

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to being naked?

ExampleWords.AUni: be naked, nakedness, nude, nudity, unclothed, nothing on, not have anything on, stripped, bare, expose (oneself)

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to not wearing enough clothes?

ExampleWords.AUni: dress immodestly, immodest, impropriety, indecent

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to not wanting to be naked?

ExampleWords.AUni: modest, propriety, decent

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to feeling bad if you are naked?

ExampleWords.AUni: shame, embarrassed, blush

Question.AUni: (1) What words describe the style of your clothing?

ExampleWords.AUni: style, stylish, in style, fashion, out of fashion, modern, traditional, old-fashioned
