AStr.Run: Use this domain for general words that refer to fire and for words referring to types of fire. These words may be specific for what is being burned (forest fire 'a fire burning a forest'), the size of the fire (inferno 'a very large hot fire'), or the place where the fire burns (hellfire 'the fire in hell').

Question.AUni: (1) What general words refer to a fire?

ExampleWords.AUni: fire, combustion

Question.AUni: (2) What types of fire are there?

ExampleWords.AUni: fireball, torch, firebrand, fireworks, firecracker, burn a field before planting

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to what is being burned?

ExampleWords.AUni: house fire, forest fire, grass fire, wood fire, oil fire

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to the size of the fire?

ExampleWords.AUni: spark, flame, flicker, finger, tongue, flare, blaze, conflagration, inferno, raging inferno

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to where the fire is?

ExampleWords.AUni: campfire, hellfire

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to a fire started by accident?

ExampleWords.AUni: blaze, the flames

Question.AUni: (7) What words refer to a fire started on purpose?

ExampleWords.AUni: cook fire, bonfire, controlled fire

Question.AUni: (8) What words refer to deliberately burning something?

ExampleWords.AUni: burn something, set something on fire, set fire to, torch (v)

Question.AUni: (9) What words refer to the crime of burning someone's house or field?

ExampleWords.AUni: arson, arsonist

Question.AUni: (10) What words describe something that burns easily?

ExampleWords.AUni: flammable, inflammable, combustible

Question.AUni: (11) What words describe something that will not burn?

ExampleWords.AUni: fireproof, unburnable, fire-resistant, unquenchable

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to lighting a fire.

Question.AUni: (1) What words are used of a person starting a fire?

ExampleWords.AUni: light a fire, build a fire, make a fire, start a fire, ignite, light a match, set on fire, set fire to something, blow into flames, kindle

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to something beginning to burn?

ExampleWords.AUni: catch fire, start burning, burst into flames, spark, smolder

Question.AUni: (3) What things are used to start fires?

ExampleWords.AUni: match, matchstick, matchbox, flint and steel, cigarette lighter, lighter fluid, tinderbox

Question.AUni: (4) What materials are used as kindling?

ExampleWords.AUni: kindling, tinder, punk

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words that refer to tending a fire--to keep a fire burning so that it burns well and does not go out.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to keeping a fire burning?

ExampleWords.AUni: tend a fire

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to adding fuel to a fire?

ExampleWords.AUni: feed a fire, stoke a fire, throw another log on the fire

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to blowing on a fire to make it bigger?

ExampleWords.AUni: fan a fire, fan into flames, blow on a fire, bellows, pump bellows

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to making a fire bigger?

ExampleWords.AUni: build up a fire

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to restarting a fire that has died down?

ExampleWords.AUni: rekindle

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to keeping a fire from going out, such as covering a fire with ashes to keep it from going out during the night?

ExampleWords.AUni: bank a fire

Question.AUni: (7) What words refer to taking something out of a fire?

ExampleWords.AUni: pull out of the fire, snatch from the flames

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to harvesting crops. AStr.Run: Use this domain for general words indicating the posture or stance of a person's body. Use the domains in this section for specific words for postures and for moving parts of the body. Many of these words have two meanings. One meaning is stative, indicating that the body is in a particular posture, but not moving. The other meaning is active, indicating that the person is moving his body into a particular posture. Some of these words can be used of animals or even things, if the things are perceived as being similar in posture to that of a human body.

LouwNidaCodes.Uni: 17 Stances and Events Related to Stances

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to bowing to someone--to face someone and lower your head or bend at the waist so that your upper body is lowered. The words in this domain should all be symbolic acts, that is, the culture assigns a meaning and significance to the physical action. Some cultures define it as a greeting, as an act of respect, or as an act of submission. For instance in ancient middle eastern culture bowing was an act of submission done in the presence of the king. Failure to bow was an act of rebellion punishable by death. In far eastern culture it is a greeting. In African culture it is an act of respect or done to welcome a visitor. Cultures define how a person is to bow, for instance how they are to hold their hands. A person may bow while standing, or may kneel, or even prostrate himself flat on his face. Whether both people bow is also significant. The depth of the bow can have significance. In Japan the person of lower social rank must bow deeper. In European culture a performer bows to acknowledge applause.

LouwNidaCodes.Uni: 17E Prostrate as an Act of Reverence or Supplication x

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to bowing?

ExampleWords.AUni: bow, bow down, bow to/before someone

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe how a person bows?

ExampleWords.AUni: sweeping bow, bow low, deep bow, slight bow, bow your head, his head fell, incline your head, nod, curtsy, genuflect, kowtow, prostrate, grovel

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate the significance of the bow?

ExampleWords.AUni: obeisance, worship, bow in submission/reverence/greeting

AStr.Run: Use this domain for intransitive verbs of movement referring to moving your whole body to a different location. There are many components of meaning involved in verbs of movement. They can include a source location (from), a goal location (to), a path (along), manner (walk, run), speed (race, crawl), direction (forward, back, side, up, down, toward, away from), shape of the path (straight, curve, circle, angle), relationship to some object or objects (on, hang, against, between, across, through, into, out of, onto, off of, around), proximity (near, far), multiple movements (back and forth, return, bounce), inclusion with other objects or parts of objects (join, leave, collect, disperse, unite, separate), volition (go versus drift), intransitive versus transitive (move versus move something). Some verbs of movement do not involve moving from one place to another, but express bodily movement.

LouwNidaCodes.Uni: 15 Linear Movement; 15A Move, Come/Go; 16 Non-Linear Movement

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to moving quickly or slowly.

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to moving toward, in the direction of, or near something or some place. Some languages (such as German and Polish) distinguish 'go on foot' from 'go in a vehicle'.

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to organizing things, people, events, and ideas--to think about and decide on the pattern a group of things should be arranged in, and then doing whatever is necessary to arrange them so that they can be used for some purpose. This domain is like the domain 'Arrange' except that 'Arrange' emphasizes physically moving the things, and the domain 'Organize' emphasizes the logical system. 'Organize' does not require that the things be moved, only that the logical pattern is specified.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to organizing things?

ExampleWords.AUni: organize, dispose, structure, get together, get it together, get your act together, chart, marshal, put in a chart, put in a table, put in a matrix, sort, sort out, systematize, tabulate

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to the pattern in which things are organized?

ExampleWords.AUni: organization, ad hoc, alignment, apparatus, cycle, framework, hierarchy, mechanism, network, order, ordering, pattern, row, sequence, set-up, structure, system

Question.AUni: (3) What tools and methods are used for organizing things?

ExampleWords.AUni: table, matrix, chart, organizational chart, flow chart, grid, cubbyhole, pigeonhole, in basket, out basket

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to organizing things a second time, or organizing things after they have been disorganized?

ExampleWords.AUni: reorganize, reorganization, adjust, reform, reorder, reordering

Question.AUni: (5) What words describe things that have been organized?

ExampleWords.AUni: organized, ordered, well-ordered, orderly, in order, harmonious, shipshape, structured, systematic, tidy, everything in its place

Question.AUni: (6) What words describe a person who organizes things well?

ExampleWords.AUni: organized, methodical, neat, together

Question.AUni: (7) What words refer to when everything is organized?

ExampleWords.AUni: order

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to kicking--to hit something with your foot. The words in this domain may be distinguished by the way in which the foot moves, either in a swinging motion, or by first bending the leg and then quickly straightening it. They may also be distinguished by whether the foot moves horizontally or vertically, whether the effect is to move something or damage it, or how hard the person kicks.

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to numbers. Every language has a word for 'one', and a word for 'two'. These two numbers often have special words. So we have included a separate domain for 'one' and 'two'. In addition the numbers form a series (one, two, three...). Most languages have more than one series of numbers (first, second, third...). So we have also included a domain for each series of numbers that most languages have. Your language may have other series of numbers. Put them in the domain 'Number series'.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to a written number?

ExampleWords.AUni: number, figure, digit, numeral

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to a number of people or things?

ExampleWords.AUni: toll, statistics

Question.AUni: (3) What words describe different kinds of numbers?

ExampleWords.AUni: even, odd, positive, negative, infinite, cardinal, ordinal, whole, fraction, decimal

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to writing numbers on a series of things?

ExampleWords.AUni: number (v), numbered

Question.AUni: (5) What words indicate that there are a particular number of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: number (v)

AStr.Run: The group <numbered> fifty.
Use this domain for words related to the cardinal numbers (one, two, three)--the numbers used to count.

Question.AUni: (1) What are the cardinal numbers? (the numbers you use when you count)

ExampleWords.AUni: zero, one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, eleven, twelve, thirteen...

Question.AUni: (2) multiples of ten

ExampleWords.AUni: ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, sixty, seventy, eighty, ninety

Question.AUni: (3) multiples of one hundred

ExampleWords.AUni: one hundred, two hundred

Question.AUni: (4) multiples of one thousand

ExampleWords.AUni: one thousand, two thousand

Question.AUni: (5) numbers larger than one thousand

ExampleWords.AUni: million, billion, trillion, quadrillion

Question.AUni: (6) What words are used to refer to the numbers of a certain decimal place?

ExampleWords.AUni: the digits, the tens, hundreds, thousands, millions, billions, trillions

Question.AUni: (7) What words are used to refer to groups of a certain decimal place?

ExampleWords.AUni: tens, hundreds, thousands, tens of thousands, millions, billions, trillions

Question.AUni: (8) What words refer to a very large number?

ExampleWords.AUni: huge number, myriad, zillion, jillion, umpteen, googolplex

Question.AUni: (9) What words refer to an unlimited number?

ExampleWords.AUni: infinity, infinite, boundless, endless, limitless

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to the number one. It appears that every language has a word for 'one' and 'two', but not every language has a word for the numbers higher than two. Many languages have several words that mean 'one'.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to one?

ExampleWords.AUni: one, first, individual, single, only, the one, one apiece, one each

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to being by yourself?

ExampleWords.AUni: alone, by yourself, sole

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to doing something by yourself?

ExampleWords.AUni: alone, on your own, solo, solely

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to people doing something one by one?

ExampleWords.AUni: one by one, singly, individually

Question.AUni: (5) What words indicate that something happens or is done one time?

ExampleWords.AUni: once, one time, single time, one-off

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to the number two.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to two?

ExampleWords.AUni: two, second, two times, two-fold, double (v), twins, brace, dichotomy, deuce, dual, dyad, twain, yoke, in pairs, in twos, two by two, by twos, two at a time, two apiece, two each, both, either, neither

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to two people who do things together?

ExampleWords.AUni: couple, pair, duo, twosome, duet

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to two things that are used together?

ExampleWords.AUni: pair, twin

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to something used by two people?

ExampleWords.AUni: for two, double, two-man

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to something with two parts?

ExampleWords.AUni: double (adj), couplet, duplex

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to something used for two things?

ExampleWords.AUni: dual, twofold

Question.AUni: (7) What words indicate that something is two times the amount of something else?

ExampleWords.AUni: twice, double, twice as much (as), two times as much (as), two times what, double what

Question.AUni: (8) What words indicate that something happens or is done two times?

ExampleWords.AUni: twice, twice over, two-time

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to the ordinal numbers (first, second, third)--the numbers used to indicate the order of something in a series, such as "the first child".

Question.AUni: (1) What are the ordinal numbers?

ExampleWords.AUni: first, second, third, fourth, fifth, sixth, seven, eighth, ninth, tenth, eleventh, twelfth, thirteenth, hundredth, thousandth

AStr.Run: My parents had five boys and I am the <second>.; This book is the <third> in the series.

Use this domain for numbers that refer to the number of times something happens or is done. These numbers may be adverbs as in English (twice) or in some languages they may be verbs (to do something two times).

LouwNidaCodes.Uni: 60E Once, Twice, Three Times, Etc. x

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate the number of times something has happened? ("He fell down three times.")

ExampleWords.AUni: once, one time, single time, twice, two times, three times, thrice, four times, many times

AStr.Run: Mary washed the dress <three times>.; I have lent John money <many times>.; I have lent John money <twice>.

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe something that has happened a particular number of times?

ExampleWords.AUni: two-time, three-time

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to doing something a particular number of times (to do something once/twice/etc.)?

ExampleWords.AUni: (none in English)

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to multiples of something (single, double, triple).

LouwNidaCodes.Uni: 60F Double, Four Times As Much, Etc.

Question.AUni: (1) What words describe something that is two or three times the amount of something else?

ExampleWords.AUni: single (portion, scoop), double (adj), triple, quadruple, quintuple, two-fold, three-fold, four-fold

AStr.Run: The oldest son inherited a <double> portion.

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that something is two or three times the amount of something else?

ExampleWords.AUni: twice as much (as), two times as much (as), two times what, double what

AStr.Run: He gave you <three times what> he gave me.; He gave you <three times as much as> he gave me.

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to something becoming two or three times as much?

ExampleWords.AUni: double (vi), triple, quadruple

AStr.Run: The size of our herd <doubled> in three years.

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to making something become two or three times as much?

ExampleWords.AUni: double (vt), triple, treble, quadruple

AStr.Run: My boss <doubled> my salary.
Use this domain for words related to a group of a particular number of things or people (solo, duo, trio; alone, in threes).

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to a group of a particular number?

ExampleWords.AUni: single, duo, duet, trio, quartet, quintet, sextet, twins, triplets, quadruplets, quintuplets, sextuplets, twosome, threesome, foursome, fortnight, decade, century, millennium, dozen, score, gross

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that only one person does something?

ExampleWords.AUni: alone (adv), solo

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to a group of two?

ExampleWords.AUni: pair, couple, couplet, brace, dichotomy, deuce, dual, dyad, twain, yoke

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to a group of three?

ExampleWords.AUni: trilogy, trinity, triple, triumvirate, triune

Question.AUni: (5) What words indicate that something is done in groups of a certain number?

ExampleWords.AUni: singly, one by one, two by two, three by three, by ones, by twos, by threes, in pairs, in threes, one at a time, two at a time, three at a time

Question.AUni: (6) What words indicate that everyone is to get a certain number of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: one apiece, two apiece, three apiece, one each, two each, three each

AStr.Run: Use this domain for the numbers that refer to a fraction of something.

Question.AUni: (1) What general words refer to a fraction of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: fraction, proportion, percentage, decimal, decimal point

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to a particular fraction of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: half, one half, third, one third, two thirds, quarter, fourth, fifth, sixth, seventh, eighth, ninth, tenth

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to dividing something into a fraction of the whole?

ExampleWords.AUni: halve, quarter (v), bisect, trisect, (divide/cut/fold) in half, in two

AStr.Run: Use this domain for other series of numbers that are different from those in the previous domains.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to something made up of a certain number of parts?

ExampleWords.AUni: duplex, tandem, tripartite

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to counting--to say the numbers in order, or to use numbers to find an amount.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to saying the numbers in order?

ExampleWords.AUni: count, countdown, say your numbers

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to counting the number of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: count, count up, at the last count, keep count, keep track, keep a tally of, enumerate, enumeration

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to determining the amount of something without being exact?

ExampleWords.AUni: estimate, assess, reckon

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to determining the quantity of something a second time?

ExampleWords.AUni: recount, renumber

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to making a mistake when you count?

ExampleWords.AUni: miscalculate, miscount, lose count

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to the number or amount of something that is counted?

ExampleWords.AUni: calculation, sum, estimate, estimation, count (n)

Question.AUni: (7) What words refer to assigning a number to each thing in a series?

ExampleWords.AUni: number, assign a number, count off

Question.AUni: (8) What words describe an amount that cannot be counted?

ExampleWords.AUni: innumerable, unnumbered, uncountable, uncounted, countless

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to mathematics and arithmetic--the study of numbers.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to mathematics?

ExampleWords.AUni: mathematics, math, arithmetic, geometry, algebra, calculus, trigonometry, statistics

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to determining the amount of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: calculate, work out, figure out, make, figure, compute, solve

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate the answer in an equation?

ExampleWords.AUni: is, equals, get

AStr.Run: Two plus two <is> four.; Two added to two <equals> four.; If you add two and two, you <get> four.

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to the answer to a mathematical problem?

ExampleWords.AUni: answer, solution

Question.AUni: (5) What words are used to talk about mathematics?

ExampleWords.AUni: problem, equation, square root, squared, graph, axis

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to a person who studies mathematics?

ExampleWords.AUni: mathematician, statistician

Question.AUni: (7) What instruments are used to do mathematics?

ExampleWords.AUni: calculator, computer, abacus, slide rule

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to adding two numbers together.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to adding two numbers together?

ExampleWords.AUni: add, addition

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to adding a series of numbers?

ExampleWords.AUni: add up, tally (v), total (v)

Question.AUni: (3) What words are used for addition equations?

ExampleWords.AUni: plus, and, added to

AStr.Run: Two <plus> two is four.; Two <and> two makes four.; Two <added to> two equals four.

Question.AUni: (4) What words indicate the answer in an equation?

ExampleWords.AUni: makes

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to the total?

ExampleWords.AUni: total (n), total (adj), sum, tally (n), grand total, subtotal, gross, aggregate, amount

Question.AUni: (6) What words indicate that a particular number is the total?

ExampleWords.AUni: altogether, in total, in all, all told

Question.AUni: (7) What words indicate that the number of a group of things reaches a particular total?

ExampleWords.AUni: come to, amount to, total (v), reach, add up to, make, bring the number to, bring the total to, number (v)

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to subtracting one number from another.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to subtracting one number from another number?

ExampleWords.AUni: subtract, take, take away, deduct, subtraction

Question.AUni: (2) What words are used for subtraction equations?

ExampleWords.AUni: minus, subtracted from, from, less

AStr.Run: Four <minus> two equals two.; Two <subtracted from> four equals two.; Two <from> four is two.

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate the answer?

ExampleWords.AUni: leave, be left with

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to the answer?

ExampleWords.AUni: remainder, difference

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to multiplying one number times another.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to multiplying one number times another?

ExampleWords.AUni: multiply, multiplication, multiples of (a number)

Question.AUni: (2) What words are used for multiplication equations?

ExampleWords.AUni: multiplied by, times

AStr.Run: Two <multiplied by> two equals four.; Two <times> two makes four.

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate the answer?

ExampleWords.AUni: makes

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to the answer?

ExampleWords.AUni: product

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to dividing one number by another number.

Question.AUni: (1) What words are used of dividing one number by another number?

ExampleWords.AUni: divide, division

Question.AUni: (2) What words are used for division equations?

ExampleWords.AUni: divided by, into, go into

AStr.Run: Four <divided by> two is two.; Two <into> four equals two.; Two <goes into> four two times.

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate the answer?

ExampleWords.AUni: times

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to the answer?

ExampleWords.AUni: quotient

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words and affixes that indicate that there is more than one of something. Some languages, such as Indo-European languages, indicate plural with an affix. Other languages, such as Austronesian languages, use a separate word. Some languages also have words or affixes that indicate that there are two of something.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that there is more than one of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: -s

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that there are two of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: pair of

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words indicating that there are many things or people, or that there is much of something.

LouwNidaCodes.Uni: 59A Many, Few; 59B Much, Little; 59F Abundance, Excess, Sparing

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that there is a large amount of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: a lot of, lots of, a great deal of, a good deal of, a fair bit of, a fair amount of, much, loads of, tons of, masses of, scads of, piles of, heaps of, stacks of, a mountain of, extensive, widespread, big amount, lots and lots

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that there are a large number of things or people?

ExampleWords.AUni: a lot of, lots of, many, many of, a large number of, large numbers of, plenty of, loads of, tons of, masses of, scads of, a bunch of, dozens of, numerous, a host of, quite a few, a wide range of, a raft of, multi-, multiple, a multitude of, considerable, goodly number, plethora, profuse, oodles, scores of

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate that there are a very large number of things or people?

ExampleWords.AUni: hundreds of, thousands of, millions of, a great many, countless, innumerable, overwhelming, myriad

Question.AUni: (4) What words indicate that many things are happening?

ExampleWords.AUni: flood of, wave of, deluge of, avalanche of, stream, torrent

Question.AUni: (5) What words indicate that many bad things are happening?

ExampleWords.AUni: spate of, epidemic, rash of, wave, be a hotbed of

Question.AUni: (6) What words indicate that many people are doing something?

ExampleWords.AUni: in large numbers, in droves, in force, in strength, thick and fast, be dying like flies, be dropping like flies

Question.AUni: (7) What words describe something that many people are doing?

ExampleWords.AUni: common, popular, widespread, widely

Question.AUni: (8) What words indicate that someone does something a lot?

ExampleWords.AUni: a lot, a good deal, a great deal, quite a bit, plenty, heavy

Question.AUni: (9) What words describe something that contains a lot of a particular substance?

ExampleWords.AUni: high in, rich in

Question.AUni: (10) What words describe someone who makes many things?

ExampleWords.AUni: productive, prolific

Question.AUni: (11) What words refer to using or giving a lot of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: generous, liberal

Question.AUni: (12) What words describe a large number or amount?

ExampleWords.AUni: large, big, high, sizable, considerable, substantial, significant, generous, handsome, hefty

Question.AUni: (13) What words describe a very large number or amount?

ExampleWords.AUni: huge, enormous, vast, massive, colossal, goodly, immense, whopping

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related there being few or little of something.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that there is a small amount of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: a little, a bit of, a small amount of, trace, trickle, dab, an element of, a touch of, a hint of, taste of, dearth, grain, hair, inappreciable, inconsequential, inconsiderable, infinitesimal, insignificant, iota, limited, minimum, minute, mite, moderate, modest, modicum, ounce, particle, poor, scant, scanty, scintilla, shred, slight, smidgen, some, speck, spoonful, suggestion, suspicion, tidbit, tinge, tiny, trifle, whit

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that there is a very small amount of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: not much, very little, to speak of, hardly any, scarcely any, almost no, minimal, negligible, precious little, next to nothing, a smattering of, a scrap of, tiny, minute

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate that there are a small number of things or people?

ExampleWords.AUni: few, a small number of, one or two, a handful of, sparse, not many, a couple of

Question.AUni: (4) What words indicate that there are a very small number of things or people?

ExampleWords.AUni: very few

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to a small amount of food?

ExampleWords.AUni: a little, a drop of, pinch, dash, mouthful, in moderation, meager

Question.AUni: (6) What words describe something that contains a little of a particular substance?

ExampleWords.AUni: low in

Question.AUni: (7) What words refer to a small amount of money?

ExampleWords.AUni: next to nothing, nominal, a drop in the ocean, paltry, miserly, a pittance, peanuts

Question.AUni: (8) What words refer to a small number of people that are part of a larger group?

ExampleWords.AUni: a minority of

Question.AUni: (9) What words indicate that few people are doing something?

ExampleWords.AUni: a trickle, in dribs and drabs, in ones and twos

Question.AUni: (10) What words refer to using or giving a little of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: dab (v), spoon out, frugal, parsimonious, scrimp, be sparing, stingy, stint

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words that refer to a group of things.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to a group of things?

ExampleWords.AUni: group, collection, lot, cluster, clump, assortment, accumulation, aggregate, bits-and-pieces, nuts-and-bolts, odds-and-ends, stockpile, system, volley, wares

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to a group of things that belong together?

ExampleWords.AUni: set, batch, suit

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to a group of things that are tied or joined together?

ExampleWords.AUni: bundle, bunch, sheaf, pack, package, packet, string of

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to a group of things that are put on top of each other?

ExampleWords.AUni: pile, stack, heap

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to a group of things that are moved together?

ExampleWords.AUni: cargo, contents, freight, goods, lading, load

Question.AUni: (6) What words indicate that something is a member of a group?

ExampleWords.AUni: member, one of, part of, belong to, go with

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to there being more of something.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to more of something in addition to what is already there?

ExampleWords.AUni: more, extra, another, added, additional, further, supplementary, spare

AStr.Run: We need more food.

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate an amount that is more than an amount already mentioned?

ExampleWords.AUni: more than, over and above, as well as, plus, in addition to, on top of

AStr.Run: We need five chickens in addition to the ten we already have.

Question.AUni: (3) What words describe something that is more than another thing in number or amount?

ExampleWords.AUni: more, greater, higher, to a greater extent, to a greater degree

AStr.Run: I own more land than you.

Question.AUni: (4) What words indicate that the actual number is more than a particular number?

ExampleWords.AUni: more, over, above, beyond, greater than, in excess of, upwards of, plus, at least

AStr.Run: More than 100 people came to the wedding.

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to something being more than a particular number or amount?

ExampleWords.AUni: be more than, be greater than, exceed, outnumber, be up on, pass, go past, surpass

AStr.Run: My land is more than five acres.

Question.AUni: (6) What words indicate that there are many more of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: many more, much more, far more, far beyond, way beyond, a lot more

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words that indicate that the number or amount of something is less than the number or amount of another thing.

Question.AUni: (1) What words describe something that is less than another thing in number or amount?

ExampleWords.AUni: less, fewer, not as much, not so much, not as many, not so many, lower, to a lesser degree, to a lesser extent, be in the minority, fewer and fewer, less and less, not more than, at the most

AStr.Run: I own less land than you.

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that something is less than a particular number or amount?

ExampleWords.AUni: less than, under, below, lower, within, minus

AStr.Run: My land is less than five acres.

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate that there is much less of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: much less, far less, far fewer, way below

Question.AUni: (4) What words indicate that something is less in some quality than another thing?

ExampleWords.AUni: less, not as, not so

Question.AUni: (5) What words indicate that something happens less or is done less?

ExampleWords.AUni: not as much, not so much

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to something increasing in number or amount--to be more than before.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to something increasing in number or amount?

ExampleWords.AUni: increase, go up, rise, grow, climb, gain, escalate, pick up, improve, widen, augment, expand

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe something that is increasing in number or amount?

ExampleWords.AUni: increasing, rising, growing, mounting, escalating, expanding, more and more, cumulative

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to increasing a lot?

ExampleWords.AUni: multiply, double, treble, quadruple, proliferate, snowball

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to increasing very quickly?

ExampleWords.AUni: shoot up, soar, rocket, go through the roof, spiral, take off, jump

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to increasing slowly?

ExampleWords.AUni: accumulate, build up, pile up, collect, gather, mount up

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to causing something to increase?

ExampleWords.AUni: increase (vt), raise, put up, push up, drive up, force up, boost, maximize

Question.AUni: (7) What words refer to increasing something by adding to it?

ExampleWords.AUni: add to, strengthen, swell, augment, supplement

Question.AUni: (8) What words refer to increasing what a machine is doing?

ExampleWords.AUni: turn up

Question.AUni: (9) What words refer to an increase in number or amount?

ExampleWords.AUni: increase (n), growth, rise, raise, build-up, upturn, hike, increment, proliferation, addition, supplement

Question.AUni: (10) What words refer to a large increase?

ExampleWords.AUni: leap, surge, explosion, boom, jump

Question.AUni: (11) What words indicate that something happens or someone does something more than before?

ExampleWords.AUni: increasingly, gain ground, get more and more, become more and more, grow in, gain in

Question.AUni: (12) What words describe something that someone is doing or feeling more than before?

ExampleWords.AUni: increased, heightened, greater, higher

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to something decreasing in number or amount--to be less than before.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to something decreasing in number or amount?

ExampleWords.AUni: decrease, fall, go down, come down, slide, diminish, contract, shrink, lessen, reduce, reduction, depreciate, lose, narrow, slow down, abate, peter out, tail off, waste away

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe something that is decreasing in number or amount?

ExampleWords.AUni: decreasing, declining, falling, lowering, shrinking, less and less, fewer and fewer

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to decreasing very quickly?

ExampleWords.AUni: drop, plummet, plunge, nosedive, slump, collapse, go through the floor

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to decreasing slowly?

ExampleWords.AUni: dwindle, decline, be on the decline, taper off, drop off, die down, ease off

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to a decrease in number or amount?

ExampleWords.AUni: decrease (n), reduction, drop, fall, decline, downturn, loss, cut, slump, collapse

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to a quality becoming less?

ExampleWords.AUni: lessen, subside, wane, ebb, recede

Question.AUni: (7) What words indicate that something happens or someone does something less than before?

ExampleWords.AUni: decreasingly, lose ground, become less and less, get less and less

Question.AUni: (8) What words describe something that someone is doing or feeling less than before?

ExampleWords.AUni: decreased, lowered, lower

Question.AUni: (9) What words refer to causing something to decrease?

ExampleWords.AUni: reduce, lower, decrease, cut, slash, roll back, knock down, halve, minimize, abbreviate, abridge, curtail, dilate, drain

Question.AUni: (10) What words refer to reducing the amount of something you use or how much you do?

ExampleWords.AUni: reduce, cut down on, scale down, scale back, cut back, trim, pare down, downsize, scrimp

Question.AUni: (11) What words refer to reducing pain or a bad feeling?

ExampleWords.AUni: reduce, lessen, relieve, ease, alleviate, deaden, dull, take the edge off, allay, mitigate

Question.AUni: (12) What words refer to decreasing what a machine is doing?

ExampleWords.AUni: reduce, lower, turn down

Question.AUni: (13) What words refer to something slowly reducing the number or amount of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: erode, eat into, deplete, whittle away

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to all.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to all of a group of things?

ExampleWords.AUni: all, everything, the lot, every, each, without exception, altogether, total, a hundred percent, whatsoever, whichever

AStr.Run: <Each> went his separate way.; <each> person

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to all of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: all, whole, entire, the lot, every bit of, every inch of, every drop of, in its entirety, from start to finish, the whole of, totality

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to all of what you want?

ExampleWords.AUni: whatever, anything, everything but the kitchen sink, you name it

Question.AUni: (4) What words describe something that affects or includes everything?

Question.AUni: (8) What words refer to all ways?

ExampleWords.AUni: every way, all-out

Use this domain for words related to most--more than half and less than all of something.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to most of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: most, almost all, nearly all, the majority, the bulk of, the better part of, the best part of, the lion's share, the biggest slice of the cake

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate that most of a group is of one kind.

ExampleWords.AUni: mostly, mainly, largely, predominantly, predominate, be in the majority, a preponderance

Question.AUni: (4) What words indicate that something happens or someone does something more than anything else?

ExampleWords.AUni: mostly, mainly, in most cases, most of the time

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to less than half of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: minority

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to the most--the largest number or amount; or the least--the smallest number or amount. Most/least may refer to the largest/smallest number possible or needed. If there are several groups being counted, most/least may refer to the largest/smallest group.

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to a number or amount that is almost the same as another number.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that something is almost a particular number or amount?

ExampleWords.AUni: almost, nearly, close to, close on, approaching, nearing, not quite, be pushing, pretty well

AStr.Run: He is almost 100 years old.

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that someone has almost reached a place?

ExampleWords.AUni: almost, nearly, just about

AStr.Run: We are <almost> there.

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate that something has almost reached a particular state?

ExampleWords.AUni: almost, nearly, very nearly, just about, practically, virtually, all but, as good as, to all intents and purposes, nearing, approaching, near to, close to, verging on, bordering on, more or less, pretty much, not quite

AStr.Run: The clothes are <almost> dry.

Question.AUni: (4) What words indicate that something is almost finished?

ExampleWords.AUni: almost, nearly, just about, practically, as good as, more or less, not quite

AStr.Run: We are <almost> finished.

Question.AUni: (5) What words indicate that someone almost does something?

ExampleWords.AUni: almost, nearly, very nearly, come close to, be on the verge of, come within an inch of

AStr.Run: I <almost> hit you.

Question.AUni: (6) What words indicate that something almost happens?

ExampleWords.AUni: almost, be near to, be on the brink of, come within an inch of

AStr.Run: He <almost> died.

Question.AUni: (7) What words indicate that something is almost the best or worst example of some quality?

ExampleWords.AUni: almost, nearly, practically, virtually, just about, verging on, bordering on

AStr.Run: He is <almost> the worst student in the school.

Question.AUni: (8) What words indicate that something is so similar to something that it is almost the same thing?

ExampleWords.AUni: almost, practically, virtually

AStr.Run: That dog is <almost> human.

Question.AUni: (9) What words indicate that something is almost some quality (such as some color or shape)?

ExampleWords.AUni: almost, more or less, practically, virtually, not quite

AStr.Run: The road is <almost> straight.

Question.AUni: (10) What words indicate that something is true of or has happened to almost all of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: almost, nearly, practically, virtually, pretty well, more or less, just about

AStr.Run: <Almost> everyone is sick.
Use this domain for words referring to only a particular number or amount of people or things--no more than one, or no more than a particular number or amount.

Question.AUni: (1) What words describe the only person or thing?

ExampleWords.AUni: only, sole, the one, lone, solitary, alone, one and only, single

AStr.Run: I had four brothers, but I am the <only> one who is still alive.

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that there is only a particular number or amount of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: only, just, no more than, all

AStr.Run: We <only> have five chairs.

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate something is true of only one thing or one group of things, and not true of others?

ExampleWords.AUni: only, just, exclusively, nothing but, nothing else, be limited to, be restricted to, be confined to, be unique to, be peculiar to, exclusive

AStr.Run: <Only> men can grow beards.

Question.AUni: (4) What words indicate that something is only what you say it is, and not something more?

ExampleWords.AUni: only, just, purely, merely, mere, nothing but

AStr.Run: He doesn't understand--he's <only> a child.; I don't want anything--I <only> want to help.

ExampleWords.AUni: exact, accurate, faithful, strict, literal, word for word, just

Question.AUni: (6) What words indicate that something is done in exactly the right way?

ExampleWords.AUni: exactly, strictly, religiously, to the letter

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words that indicate whether a number or amount is approximate.

AStr.Run: It weighs <about> four kilos.; John walks <approximately> two miles a day.

ExampleWords.AUni: estimate (n), approximation, ballpark figure, round figure

Question.AUni: (9) What words indicate that something happens at an approximate time?

ExampleWords.AUni: about, around, approximately, round about, or thereabouts, circa, some time

Question.AUni: (10) What words indicate that something happens at an approximate place?

Question.AUni: (11) What words describe something that is approximately the same as another thing?

Question.AUni: (12) What words indicate that something is done in approximately the right way?

ExampleWords.AUni: roughly, more or less, somewhat

ExampleWords.AUni: loose, vague, hazy, impressionistic, broad

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to being or having enough--to have as much of something or as many of something as you need or want.

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to being long. In many languages there is more than one system of measuring length. These systems may be used for different purposes or in different jobs. Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to the same person or thing, not a different one?

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe two things that are the same?

AStr.Run: This is <the same> as that.; The twins are <the same> in every way.

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words describing something, such as a tool or way of doing something, that is proper for a particular time, place, purpose, or job. The words in this domain involve a comparison between two things, an item and a setting. An evaluation is made as to how good the item is in the setting. The words may be used only of certain types of items, certain types of settings, or certain types of usefulness.

Question.AUni: (1) What words describe something that is proper?

ExampleWords.AUni: right, proper, applicable, apposite, apropos, becoming, befitting, correspond, correspondent, corresponding, decent, due, expected, felicitous, germane, meet, opportune, pertinent, pleasing, principled, properly, right-minded, rightful, smart, suitable, suited, timely, well, well-timed

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe something that is right for a particular job?

ExampleWords.AUni: right, proper, accepted, approved, appropriate, correct

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to something being right for a particular job?

ExampleWords.AUni: suit, lends itself to, be suited to, be cut out for, be made for, fit the bill, fit in, be right for, be the right person for, make a good/ideal

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to something someone does that is right for a particular situation?

ExampleWords.AUni: right, proper, acceptable, appropriate, apt, correct, fitting, suitable, be the done thing, be the way it's done, in keeping with

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to doing something in the right way?

ExampleWords.AUni: right, properly, correctly, by the book

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to the quality of being proper?

ExampleWords.AUni: suitability, suitableness, fit (n)

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words describing something, such as a tool or way of doing something, that is unsuitable for a particular time, place, purpose, or job.

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to something being unsuitable for a particular purpose or situation?

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to something being unsuitable because it isn't good enough?

ExampleWords.AUni: planting season, growing season, harvest season, hunger season

ExampleWords.AUni: yearly, every year, annually, annual

ExampleWords.AUni: era, age, epoch, the times, generation, this age, the age to come

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that something happens for a very short time?

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to taking a short time to do something?

ExampleWords.AUni: be brief, be quick

Question.AUni: (4) What do people say when they want someone to do something in a short time?

ExampleWords.AUni: be brief, don't take long, get it over with

Question.AUni: (2) What do people say when they want someone to do something for a long time?

ExampleWords.AUni: take your time, make it last, we want this to last a long time

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to something happening forever.

ExampleWords.AUni: forever, always, ever, eternally, incessantly, unceasingly, forever and ever, in perpetuity, for all eternity, for all time

Question.AUni: (2) What words are used to describe something will continue forever?

ExampleWords.AUni: eternal, infinite, everlasting, constant, perpetual, unending, endless, never-ending, unceasing, ceaseless, incessant, undying, immortal, imperishable, deathless, boundless, indefinite, unlimited, immeasurable, never failing, unfailing, timeless

Question.AUni: (3) What words are used to indicate that something will continue forever?

ExampleWords.AUni: be forever, last forever, go on forever, always be there, never fail/end/die/stop

Question.AUni: (4) What words are used to refer to all time or a time that will never end?

ExampleWords.AUni: eternity, infinity, all times

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to something being temporary.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that something will only last for some time and then end?

ExampleWords.AUni: temporary, transient

LouwNidaCodes.Uni: 67A A Point of Time without Reference to Other Points of Time: Time, Occasion, Ever, Often

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to an indefinite time?

ExampleWords.AUni: when, then, sometime, someday, anytime, onetime, whenever, approximate, approximately

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to telling time.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to telling time?

ExampleWords.AUni: tell time, keep time, mark time, measure time, beat time, register the time, to chronicle

Question.AUni: (2) What is a written record of times and events called?

ExampleWords.AUni: chronology, chronicle, record, history

Question.AUni: (3) What is a person called who keeps time?

ExampleWords.AUni: timekeeper

Question.AUni: (4) What words indicate a particular time?

ExampleWords.AUni: (In written English we use a semicolon to separate the hour from the minute: 5:00.)

AStr.Run: It is now five <o'clock>.; It is five <a.m.>; It is five <p.m.>; It is noon <time>.; ten minutes <after> five.; <half> <past> five.; a <quarter> <to> five.; at ten <of> six.; a <quarter> <of> an hour.; in <half> an hour.; ten minutes <past> <the hour>.
Use this domain for words referring to planning the time of an event.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to planning the time of an event?

ExampleWords.AUni: plan a time, set a date, schedule something, time something

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to the time of an event?

ExampleWords.AUni: time, date, timing

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to a plan for the time of an event?

ExampleWords.AUni: schedule, timetable, program

AStr.Run: Use this domain for machines that indicate what time it is.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to machines for telling time?

ExampleWords.AUni: timepiece, watch, clock, alarm clock, digital watch, analog watch, electric clock, sundial, pendulum, hourglass

AStr.Run: Use the domains in this section for words that relate one time to another. Use this domain for words that indicate a temporal relation between situations.

LouwNidaCodes.Uni: 67 Points of Time; 67B A Point of Time with Reference to Other Points of Time: Before, Long Ago, Now, At the Same Time, When, About, After

Question.AUni: (1) What general words refer to one time in relation to another time?

ExampleWords.AUni: relative to, in relation to, before or after

AStr.Run: When did it happen <relative to> his death?

Use this domain for words referring to temporal order or sequence--the order in which a group of events happen. Things and people may also be in order based on the order in which something happened or should happen to them.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to the order or sequence of a group of events?

ExampleWords.AUni: order, sequence, cycle, pattern, rota, order of events

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to a group of events that happen in order?

ExampleWords.AUni: sequence, series, succession, chain, course, progression

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to a group of things in a series?

ExampleWords.AUni: series, lineup, queue

Question.AUni: (4) What words describe a group of things that have been put in order?

ExampleWords.AUni: be in order, ordered, in sequence, be the right way round, in chronological order, chronological, consecutive, consecutively, successive, in succession, one after another, one after the other, (three years) running, sequential

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to doing things in order?

ExampleWords.AUni: in order, take turns

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to the particular order in which something comes?

ExampleWords.AUni: place, position, where something comes

Question.AUni: (7) What words describe a group of things that have not been put in order?

ExampleWords.AUni: unordered, out of sequence

Question.AUni: (8) What words describe a group of things in the wrong order?

ExampleWords.AUni: be out of order, be in the wrong order, be the wrong way round, backwards

Question.AUni: (9) What words refer to something missing from a group of things in order?

ExampleWords.AUni: gap

Question.AUni: (10) In English 'Order' can be expressed by a noun phrase with no overt marker.

AStr.Run: the first child; the second taxi; the next person (to speak); the last person (out the door)

Question.AUni: (11) In English 'Order' can be expressed by a 'be' clause with the 'Item' in the subject position.

ExampleWords.AUni: be

AStr.Run: This child <was> first.

Question.AUni: (12) In English 'Order' can be expressed by a noun phrase with the 'Item' marked by 'of'.

ExampleWords.AUni: of

AStr.Run: the second <of> the winners
Use this domain for words related to a series--several things that happen one after another.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to a series of things, events, numbers or people?

ExampleWords.AUni: series, sequence, string of, succession of, stream, train of events, course of

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe things in a series?

ExampleWords.AUni: successive, consecutive, alternating, serial

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate that someone does things in a series?

ExampleWords.AUni: in succession, one after the other, one after another, straight, in a row, running, alternate

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to the place that something has in a series?

ExampleWords.AUni: place, order, rank, slot, grade

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to something happening first--to be before all other things in order or time.

Question.AUni: (1) What words describe something that is first in order or time?

ExampleWords.AUni: first, original, initial, earliest, inaugural, prime

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate an event or action that is first?

ExampleWords.AUni: first (adv), first of all, beginning with, starting with

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate that something happened when you first saw something?

ExampleWords.AUni: at first sight, at first glance

Question.AUni: (4) What words indicate that something is the first in a list of things that you will talk about?

ExampleWords.AUni: firstly, first of all, to start with, to begin with, in the first place

Question.AUni: (5) What words indicate that something happens or is done for the first time?

ExampleWords.AUni: first, the first time

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to the first time someone does something?

ExampleWords.AUni: debut, premiere, maiden (voyage)

Question.AUni: (7) What words describe something that has never happened before?

ExampleWords.AUni: unprecedented, a first

Question.AUni: (8) What words refer to doing something that has never been done before?

ExampleWords.AUni: be the first to do something, show the way, lead the way, pioneer, break new ground

Question.AUni: (9) What words refer to being the first person to do something in a situation instead of waiting for someone else?

ExampleWords.AUni: make the first move, take the initiative

Question.AUni: (10) What words refer to the person who did something first?

ExampleWords.AUni: pioneer, the first

Question.AUni: (11) What words refer to something that is the first of its kind?

ExampleWords.AUni: prototype, original (n)

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to something happening next.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that an event happens next?

ExampleWords.AUni: next, right afterwards, the day after, then

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe something that happens next?

ExampleWords.AUni: next, following, ensuing

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to an event happening next after another event?

ExampleWords.AUni: follow, come next, be after, be next, succeed, come after, go after, go next, ensue

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to something happening last--to happen after all other things in a sequence, or to be the last person or thing in a sequence.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that an event happens last?

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe something that happens last?

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to an event happening last?

Question.AUni: (5) What words indicate that something is next to the last?

Question.AUni: (6) What words indicate that something is the last before now?

Question.AUni: (7) What words do people use to indicate the last thing in a list of things they are talking about?

ExampleWords.AUni: lastly, finally, last but not least

Question.AUni: (8) What words refer to the last thing?

ExampleWords.AUni: the last, the latter

Question.AUni: (9) What words refer to the last part of something?

ExampleWords.AUni: end, ending, finish

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to something that happens regularly.

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to alternating--when several things happen one after another in a repeated pattern.

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to one event happening before another.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that something happens before a particular event?

ExampleWords.AUni: before (conj), prior to, on the eve of, pre-

AStr.Run: John took a bath <before> eating dinner.

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that something happens before now or before a particular time?

ExampleWords.AUni: before (adv), earlier, formerly, previously, ago, already

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate that someone does something before a particular event?

ExampleWords.AUni: beforehand, in advance, advance, prior

Question.AUni: (4) What words indicate that something must be done before a particular time?

ExampleWords.AUni: before, by, not later than, at the latest

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to something that happened before?

ExampleWords.AUni: antecedent, precedent, precedence, the one before

Question.AUni: (6) What words describe something that happened before?

ExampleWords.AUni: previous, old, last (adj), earlier, former, prior, preceding, recent, preliminary

Question.AUni: (7) What words describe a time that comes before another one?

ExampleWords.AUni: previous (day), last (night), the (week) before, the preceding (year)

Question.AUni: (8) What words indicate that something comes before another in a series?

ExampleWords.AUni: before, in front of, ahead of

Question.AUni: (9) What words describe something that comes before another in a series?

ExampleWords.AUni: previous, preceding, earlier, the one before

Question.AUni: (10) What words refer to something happening before something else?

ExampleWords.AUni: come before, precede, predate, lead up to, come first, be before, be a prelude to, anticipate, antedate

Question.AUni: (11) What words refer to coming before something else in a series?

ExampleWords.AUni: come before, precede

Question.AUni: (12) What words refer to doing something before someone else does it?

ExampleWords.AUni: do something first, be first, beat someone to it, ahead of, be ahead of your time

Question.AUni: (13) What words refer to a person or thing that existed before another?

ExampleWords.AUni: predecessor, forerunner, precursor, ex-(wife/president)

Question.AUni: (14) What words describe something that has been mentioned before?

ExampleWords.AUni: above, aforementioned, foregoing

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to one event happening after another.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that something happens after a particular time or event?

ExampleWords.AUni: after, afterward, afterwards, later, later on, subsequently, after that, beyond that, hence

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that something happens after a certain period of time?

ExampleWords.AUni: after, within, in, from now

Question.AUni: (3) What words describe something that comes after something else?

ExampleWords.AUni: next, following, later, subsequent, succeeding, ensuing, after, future, consequent, latter

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to something happening after something else?

ExampleWords.AUni: follow, come after, ensue, follow-up, be after

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to the events that happen after an event?

ExampleWords.AUni: sequel, aftermath, what follows

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to a person who takes a job or position after someone else?

ExampleWords.AUni: successor, next in line, succeed

Question.AUni: (7) What words refer to a book or film that comes after another one?

ExampleWords.AUni: sequel

Question.AUni: (8) What words indicate that something comes after another in a series?

ExampleWords.AUni: after, next, later, further on

Question.AUni: (9) What words indicate that something will not be done now, but later?

ExampleWords.AUni: later, it can wait, it will wait

Question.AUni: (10) What words are used to link events when telling a story?

ExampleWords.AUni: and, and then, then, having...-en, after, thereafter, thereon, thereupon, whereupon, upon

AStr.Run: John took a bath, <and> ate a big dinner.; John took a bath, <and then> ate a big dinner.; <Having> tak<en> a bath, John ate a big dinner.; <After> taking a bath, John ate a big dinner.
Use this domain for words referring to two things happening at the same time.

LouwNidaCodes.Uni: 67G Duration of Time with Reference to Some Unit of Time: During, In, While, Throughout

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that two things happen at the same time?

ExampleWords.AUni: at the same time, together, at one time, at once, simultaneously, at the same instant, in concert, in unison

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that something happens at the same time as something else?

ExampleWords.AUni: at the same time as, meanwhile, while, as, -ing, simultaneity, concurrently, coincident

AStr.Run: John went out to the garden, carry<ing> his hoe and shovel.; Mary bought food, <while> John got gas for the car.

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to two things happening at the same time?

ExampleWords.AUni: coincide, clash

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to arranging two events so that they happen at the same time?

ExampleWords.AUni: synchronize, tie something in with

Question.AUni: (5) What words describe things that happen at the same time?

ExampleWords.AUni: simultaneous, synchronized, parallel, synchronous, contemporaneous, concurrent

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to two people that lived at the same time?

ExampleWords.AUni: contemporary, be a contemporary of someone, be contemporaries

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words indicating that something happened during some time period, or that something happened while something else was happening.

LouwNidaCodes.Uni: 67G Duration of Time with Reference to Some Unit of Time: During, In, While, Throughout

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that something happened during some time period?

ExampleWords.AUni: during, in, in the course of, during the course of, through, throughout, over, by day, by night, during the middle of, in the interim, within

AStr.Run: It rained <during> the night.

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that something happened during the time when something else was happening?

ExampleWords.AUni: while, meanwhile, in the meantime

AStr.Run: I decided to eat something <while> I waited for the rain to stop.
Use this domain for words referring to the right time to do something.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to the right time to do something?

ExampleWords.AUni: the right time, a good time, be the time

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe something happening at the right time?

ExampleWords.AUni: timely, opportune, well-timed, come at the right time

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to a person's ability to choose the right time to do something?

ExampleWords.AUni: timing, sense of timing

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to the wrong time to do something?

ExampleWords.AUni: the wrong time, a bad time, not a good time, be no time, not be the time

Question.AUni: (5) What words describe something happening at the wrong time?

ExampleWords.AUni: badly-timed, ill-timed, come at the wrong time, at a bad time, inopportune

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words that indicate that something happens early--before the expected time, before the usual time, or before the time that was agreed on. Some words may include the idea that it is good that the event happened early. Other words may include the idea that it is bad that the event happened early.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that something happens early?

ExampleWords.AUni: early (adv), ahead of time, ahead of schedule, in good time

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe something that happens early?

ExampleWords.AUni: early (adj)

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to something happening early?

ExampleWords.AUni: be early

Question.AUni: (4) What words indicate that something happens too early?

ExampleWords.AUni: too early, too soon, untimely, premature, prematurely, jump the gun

Question.AUni: (5) What words indicate that something happens early in the morning?

ExampleWords.AUni: early, first thing, at the crack of dawn, bright and early

Question.AUni: (6) What words indicate that something will happen no earlier than a particular time?

ExampleWords.AUni: at the earliest, no earlier than

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words describing something happening on time--at the expected time, at the usual time, or at the time that was agreed on.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that something happens on time?

ExampleWords.AUni: on time, right on time, punctually, promptly, on cue, on the dot, at the right time, at the designated time, at the appointed time, when expected, right when it was supposed to happen, at the exact moment

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe something that happens on time?

ExampleWords.AUni: timely

Question.AUni: (3) What words describe someone who does things on time?

ExampleWords.AUni: punctual, prompt

Question.AUni: (4) What words indicate that something happens before it is too late?

ExampleWords.AUni: in time, just in time, in the nick of time, not a moment too soon, at the last minute, at the eleventh hour, catch, cut it fine, cut it too close, made it in by a whisker, just under the wire

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to finishing something within the time that is allowed?

ExampleWords.AUni: meet a deadline, on schedule

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words describing something happening late--after the expected time, after the usual time, or after the time that was agreed on.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that something happens late?

ExampleWords.AUni: late (adv), not on time, lateness (of the hour), late in life

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe something that happens late?

ExampleWords.AUni: late (adj), overdue, belated

Question.AUni: (3) What words describe someone who is late?

ExampleWords.AUni: tardy, latecomer

Question.AUni: (4) What do people say to someone who is late?

ExampleWords.AUni: about time too, what time do you call this? where have you been? better late than never

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to being late to pay back a loan?

ExampleWords.AUni: be behind with, overdue, be in arrears

Question.AUni: (6) What words indicate that something happens late at night?

ExampleWords.AUni: last thing at night, in the middle of the night, the early hours, till all hours

Question.AUni: (7) What words refer to not finishing something within the time that is allowed?

ExampleWords.AUni: be behind, be behind schedule, be running late, overrun

Question.AUni: (8) What words indicate that something is too late?

ExampleWords.AUni: too late, it's a little late in the day, leave it a bit late, miss

Question.AUni: (9) What words indicate that something will happen no later than a particular time?

ExampleWords.AUni: no later than, at the latest

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to something delaying someone or something--to cause something to happen at a later time, cause someone to do something at a later time, or cause someone or something to be late.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to something delaying someone?

ExampleWords.AUni: delay, make someone late, hold someone up, keep, detain

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to something delaying an event?

ExampleWords.AUni: delay, hold something up, set back, put back, get bogged down

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to an instance of delaying something?

ExampleWords.AUni: delay (n), hold-up

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to deliberately delaying someone in order to accomplish something?

ExampleWords.AUni: stall, play for time, delaying tactics

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to postponing something--to decide to do something later.

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to postponing something because you are lazy?

ExampleWords.AUni: put off, procrastinate

Question.AUni: (3) What do people say when they postpone doing something?

Use this domain for words referring to a time period that is part of a longer time period.

Question.AUni: (1) What general words refer to part of a longer time period?

ExampleWords.AUni: phase, aspect

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to starting something, or for something beginning to happen.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to starting something?

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to officially starting something such as a new law or way of doing something?

ExampleWords.AUni: introduce, bring in, phase in

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to starting an organization?

ExampleWords.AUni: start, start up, open, set up, establish, found, inception

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to something starting a natural process?

ExampleWords.AUni: start, activate, set off

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to starting something again after it has stopped?

ExampleWords.AUni: restart, bring back, reintroduce, revive, restore, resurrect

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to something beginning to happen, to beginning to do something, to cause something to start happening, or to cause people to start doing something.

Question.AUni: (1) What words are used to indicate that something has begun?

ExampleWords.AUni: begin, start, commence, initiate, to institute

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to the time when something begins?

ExampleWords.AUni: beginning, the start, commencement, inception, at first, initially, originally

Question.AUni: (3) What do people say when they want someone else to start?

ExampleWords.AUni: go, dig in, have at it, let's go, let's do it, move it, let's get going, "on your marks, get set, go", "ready, set, go"

Question.AUni: (4) What is a person called who starts something?

ExampleWords.AUni: initiator, founder, originator, starter

Question.AUni: (5) What words indicate that some state has begun?

ExampleWords.AUni: achieve, appear, arrive, attain

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to the end of an action or situation.

Question.AUni: (1) What words (intransitive verbs) indicate that something has ended?

ExampleWords.AUni: stop, come to rest, halt, come to a screeching halt

Question.AUni: (2) What words (transitive verbs) indicate that someone is stopping something?

ExampleWords.AUni: end (something), stop (something), stanch (flow of blood), obstruct (justice), arrest (progress), halt (traffic), impede (progress), inhibit (flow), delay (someone/event), hold up (traffic), detain (someone), discontinue (product), suspend (action), terminate (someone's life), conclude (story), cease (hostilities), desist from (doing something), bring closure to (something), curtail

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to the event of stopping?

ExampleWords.AUni: halt, standstill, pause, discontinuance, stoppage, stay, closure

Question.AUni: (4) Where do things typically stop?

ExampleWords.AUni: stopping place, station

Question.AUni: (5) What things are used to stop things?

ExampleWords.AUni: brake, catch, skid

Question.AUni: (6) What do people say when they want someone to stop?

ExampleWords.AUni: Halt! Stay! Cease and desist! Belay that order! Avast!

Question.AUni: (7) What words describe something that you can't stop doing?

ExampleWords.AUni: compulsive

Question.AUni: (8) What words indicate that some state has ended?

ExampleWords.AUni: cease, finish, stop

Question.AUni: (9) What words refer to something stopping gradually?

ExampleWords.AUni: fade away, wear off, go away, die away

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to the end of an action or situation.

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words that indicate that something will continue to happen until a particular time or until something else happens, and then it will stop.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that something will happen until something else happens?

ExampleWords.AUni: (In written English a hyphen is used to indicate that something happens from one time until another time, as in "8:00-5:00" or "Monday-Friday".)

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that something will not happen until something else happens?

ExampleWords.AUni: until, wait until

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words that indicate that something will start to happen at some time and continue for some time.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that something starts to happen after a particular time and then continues?

ExampleWords.AUni: starting, from, as from, after that

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that something started in the past and continued until now?

ExampleWords.AUni: since, ever since, for, from, starting from, from that time on, thereafter

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate that something starts to happen now and will continue?

ExampleWords.AUni: from now on, from this time forward, starting now, starting from now, effective immediately, henceforth

Question.AUni: (4) What words indicate that something will start in the future and continue?

ExampleWords.AUni: from then on, starting then

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to the past or to a time in the past.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to the past?

ExampleWords.AUni: past, before, in the past, in years gone by, in the times of our fathers, in our father's/grandparent's/ancestor's time, was (being/doing/happening), lately

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe something that existed or happened in the past?

ExampleWords.AUni: earlier, foregoing

Question.AUni: (3) What words describe something that existed or happened long ago?

ExampleWords.AUni: the distant past, long ago

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words indicating that something happened recently--a short time before now.

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that an event happened a very short time ago?

ExampleWords.AUni: just, only just, a moment ago, a minute ago, just this minute, barely, scarcely, hardly

AStr.Run: It <just> happened.

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate that something has been happening up until now?

ExampleWords.AUni: current, present, present-day

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words describing something old--a word describing something that has existed for a long time.

Use this domain for words referring to doing something at a quick speed or something happening quickly.

ExampleWords.AUni: over there, elsewhere, yon, yonder

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words that express the idea that something contains something.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that something contains something?

ExampleWords.AUni: have, of, -'s, contain, hold

Question.AUni: (2) In English 'Containership' can be expressed by a clause using the verb 'contain' with the 'Container' in the subject position and the 'Content' in the object position.

AStr.Run: The cup <contained> milk.

Question.AUni: (3) In English 'Containership' can be expressed by a clause using the verb with the 'Container' in the subject position, the 'Content' in the object position, and the 'Container' in a preposition phrase marked by 'in'.

AStr.Run: The cup <has> milk <in it>.

Question.AUni: (4) In English 'Containership' can be expressed by a noun phrase with the 'Container' as the head and the 'Content' marked by 'of'.

AStr.Run: a cup <of> milk

Question.AUni: (5) In English 'Containership' can be expressed by a noun phrase with the word 'container' as the head and the 'Content' marked by 'of'.

AStr.Run: the <container> <of> milk

Question.AUni: (6) In English 'Containership' can be expressed by a noun phrase with the word 'contents' as the head and the 'Container' marked by 'of'.

AStr.Run: the <contents> <of> the cup

Question.AUni: (7) In English 'Containership' can be expressed by a possession phrase with the 'Container' in the first position and the word 'contents' in the second position.

AStr.Run: the cup<'s> <contents>

ExampleWords.AUni: noun, verb, adjective, adverb, conjunction, preposition, particle, article, word, participle, infinitive, part of speech, compound, derivative
